Special Abilities.name: Special Abilities
Special Abilities.text:
Bestiary

This selection of creatures and monsters details the special abilities possessed by the monsters your heroes must fight. Also included are some commonly occurring beasts of Golarion. You'll find dozens more exotic and dangerous fearsome foes in the Pathfinder for Savage Worlds Bestiary.

Special Abilities

All-Around Vision

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.All-Around Vision]{Link to Special Ability}

A few creatures possess the remarkable ability to see in all directions, usually because of unique physical features. Creatures with All-Around Vision ignore one point of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Gang Up} bonuses, add +2 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice} rolls made to resist attacks from @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Stealth]{Stealth}, and cannot be the target of a Sneak Attack.

Ancestry

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Ancestry]{Link to Special Ability}

Many humanoids have universal features common to their ancestry. These include special @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powers00000001]{abilities}, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edges}, and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrances0000]{Hindrances}. Goblins have @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Darkvision]{Darkvision}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Size]{Size} −1, and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Greedy]{Greedy} (Major), for example. Some non-humanoids and other creature types may also have a universal set of features— such as archons, demons, and devils— when there are different versions within a creature category.

Instead of listing each of these features separately, they are listed together in one bullet in the creature’s stat block, such as “Ancestry (Goblin)” or “Archons.”

Aquatic

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Aquatic]{Link to Special Ability}

The creature is native to the water. It is a natural swimmer and cannot drown. Its @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Pace} in water is specified after the Aquatic ability.

Armor

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Armor]{Link to Special Ability}

A creature’s Armor is written in parentheses next to its total Toughness, and already added in. Thick, leathery hide generally offers 2 points of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02armor000000000]{Armor}. Creatures like a stegosaurus generally have 4 or more points of protection. Supernatural creatures may have much higher Armor values. A living statue, for example, might have 8 points of Armor or more.

Bash

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Bash]{Link to Special Ability}

Larger creatures often use their bodies or body parts to pummel their opponents during combat. See the creature’s statistics for any special effects.

Bite

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Bite]{Link to Special Ability}

See @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Natural Weapons]{Natural Weapons}.

Blindsense

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Blindsense]{Link to Special Ability}

A creature with this ability can perceive its environment using non-visual senses. This includes a keen sense of smell, echolocation, or sensing vibrations in the ground or even in the air. These creatures ignore @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Invisibility]{invisibility}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Illusion]{illusion}, and all @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination} penalties.

Breath Weapons

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Breath Weapons]{Link to Special Ability}

Most dragons and other “fire breathers” use a Cone Template for their attacks (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Area Effect} attacks). A few specific creatures, such as blue and black dragons, use the Stream Template.

All breath attacks may be Evaded (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Evasion}).

Unless the creature’s description says otherwise, breath attacks take the creature’s entire turn— they can’t perform @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Multi-Actions} in the same round they make a breath attack.

Burrow

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Burrow]{Link to Special Ability}

From massive worms to sand-dwelling humanoids, many creatures are able to burrow beneath the earth and move within it.

Burrowers can tunnel underground and reappear elsewhere for devastating surprise attacks against their foes. The distance a creature can burrow on its turn is written immediately after its Burrow ability.

A burrowing creature may tunnel as an action, and may erupt from the ground at any point within its burrowing @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Pace} in the same turn. It cannot be attacked while beneath the earth unless the attacker has some special means of detecting it and penetrating the intervening dirt.

Burrowing creatures erupt from beneath their opponents and may take them by @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{surprise}. If the target was unaware of the burrower’s presence, the creature makes an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{opposed} @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Stealth]{Stealth} roll versus the victim’s @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice}. If the burrower wins, the target is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Vulnerable} to it only. With a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise}, the burrower gets @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{the drop}. Targets on @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Hold} may attempt to interrupt the attack before it occurs.

Burrowers can’t usually surprise a foe once their presence is known, but can still burrow for protection and mobility.

Class Abilities

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Class Abilities]{Link to Special Ability}

When a creature has a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edgesummarie00]{Class Edge}, the specific features of the Edge are listed in a single bullet. A goblin warchanter, for example, has the Bard Class Edge, with all its features listed in a single bullet labeled “Class Abilities (Bard).”

Claws

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Claws]{Link to Special Ability}

See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Natural Weapons}.

Construct

Golems and other animated objects are collectively called “constructs.” Some are sentient beings while others are mere automatons following the will of their masters.

Whatever their origin or material, constructs have several inherent advantages over creatures of flesh and blood.

Constructs add +2 when attempting to recover from being @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}, ignore 1 point of Wound penalties, don’t breathe or eat and are immune to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{disease} and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{poison}, don’t @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03healing0000000]{Bleed Out}, and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} are removed with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Repair]{Repair} instead of @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Healing]{Healing} with no @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03healing0000000]{"Golden Hour"}

darkvision

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Darkvision]{Link to Special Ability}

Some creatures on Golarion possess the extraordinary ability to see without a light source. Creatures with this ability ignore penalties for @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination} up to 10″ (20 yards).

Energy drain

With a successful touch or attack, a victim must make a resistance roll (usually with @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor}) or lose a die type in the targeted attribute.

If the attack would reduce an attribute below d4, the victim is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated} until healed or he recovers a lost die type (see below). If the targeted attribute was Vigor, he must make a Vigor roll at the end of his next turn or perish.

Recovery: Unless slain, a victim recovers one die type every 24 hours, or if given respite with the Restoration modifier of @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Relief]{relief}.

Elemental

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Elemental]{Link to Special Ability}

Air, earth, fire, and water form the basis of the elemental realms, wherein dwell strange, unfathomable creatures.

Elementals have bodies of pure earth, water, air, or fire and are immune to damage, effects, or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping}s that match their native element. They also ignore additional damage from @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Called Shots}, ignore one point of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound} penalties, don’t breathe or eat, are immune to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{disease} and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{poison}, and can only be healed via magic or natural @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03healing0000000]{Healing}.

Environmental Resistance

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Environmental Resistance]{Link to Special Ability}

The creature is resistant (but not immune) to a particular type of energy or matter such as cold, heat, electricity, cold iron, etc.

Damage from that source is reduced by 4, and the being adds +4 to resist matching @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{Hazards} and powers with a similar @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping}.

Environmental Weakness

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Environmental Weakness]{Link to Special Ability}

The creature is susceptible to a particular type of energy or matter, such as cold, heat, electricity, cold iron, etc.

The creature takes +4 damage from that source, and subtracts 4 when resisting @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{Hazards} or powers with a similar @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping}.

Ethereal

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Ethereal]{Link to Special Ability}

Ghosts, shadows, will-o’-wisps, and similar intangible creatures have no form in the physical world (or can turn it on and off at will). They can pass through physical objects, cannot be harmed by non-magical attacks, and cannot even be seen unless they desire to be. Ethereal creatures are affected by magical items, weapons, and supernatural powers.

Unless its description says otherwise, ethereal creatures can throw objects, wield weapons, or even push terrified heroes down long, dark stairs.

Fear

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Fear]{Link to Special Ability}

Particularly frightening monsters cause Fear checks to all who see them. Some truly terrifying monsters may inflict penalties on Fear checks as well. A creature with Fear −2, for instance, causes those who see it to make their Fear checks at −2. See the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04fear0000000000]{Fear} rules for effects.

Fearless

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Fearless]{Link to Special Ability}

Mindless creatures, such as some undead, constructs, and the like, don’t suffer from the weaknesses of the mortal mind. Fearless creatures are immune to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Fear]{Fear} effects and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation}. They may still be @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunted}, however (usually because it draws their attention rather than causing emotional distress).

Flight

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Flight]{Link to Special Ability}

The creature can fly at the listed @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Pace}. It uses its @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} to maneuver in chases or other situations.

If a creature’s Pace is at least 24 and it's flying, attackers subtract 1 when making attacks against it. If it’s Pace is 48 or higher, attackers subtract 2.

Gargantuan

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Gargantuan]{Link to Special Ability}

Gargantuan creatures are those that are at least @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size} 12 or higher. They have Heavy Armor (not to be confused with the heavy category of personal armor), can take three additional @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds}, and their attacks count as @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Heavy Weapons}.

Stomp: A Gargantuan creature may stomp by using an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{area effect} template (the size of the template is determined by the GM based on the monster’s “footprint”). The attack ignores @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Scale} modifiers and is an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{opposed} @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} vs @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Agility} roll (defenders roll individually). Those who can’t get out of the way are stomped for damage equal to the monster’s Strength damage.

Hardy

Very tough or determined creatures do not fall from lesser injuries, no matter how many they suffer. A decisive blow is needed to put one of these tenacious creatures down.

If the beast is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}, another Shaken result doesn’t cause a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound}.

Horns

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Horns]{Link to Special Ability}

See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Natural Weapons}.

Immunity

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Immunity]{Link to Special Ability}

Creatures born in fire aren’t affected by heat, and a horror made of pure lightning won’t suffer from a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Bolt]{bolt} attack with an electrical @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping}. Immunities are to specific types of attacks, such as fire, cold, electricity, and so on. Such creatures don’t have @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Invulnerability]{Invulnerability} (see below), they just ignore damage and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stun} results from the specific attack types named.

Infection

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Infection]{Link to Special Ability}

A vampire’s bite, a horrid spider-like creature that injects eggs into its victim’s skin, or the scratches of certain vermin might all cause Infection.

A character @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} by a creature with Infection must make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll. Modifiers to the roll are listed in the creature’s description, as are the effects of failure.

Innate Powers

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Innate Powers]{Link to Special Ability}

Various creatures on Golarion have innate powers. These are usually magical abilities with "spell-like" effects or powers.

Unless otherwise noted, activating an innate power is an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{action} and doesn't require a roll. A minor ability "casts" the listed power with basic success, and a major ability casts as if with a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise}.

If an ability requires a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Trait roll} instead, it's listed after the power (and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Critical Failure} causes @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Fatigue}). Those that don't require a Trait roll are simply described as minor or major, like so:

  • Innate Powers: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Invisibility]{Invisibility} (@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Spirit}), @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Puppet]{minor puppet}.

Duration: Unless a creature's description lists a particular @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{Duration}, Innate Powers may be maintained indefinitely, but terminate instantly if the creature is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned}.

Invulnerability

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Invulnerability]{Link to Special Ability}

Invulnerable creatures ignore damage as listed in their description. Unless otherwise specified, they can be @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned} but not @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} by other forms of damage. An ancient dark god given life by misguided cultists, for example, might only be vulnerable to relics of a rival deity.

Low Light Vision

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Low Light Vision]{Link to Special Ability}

Low Light Vision ignores penalties for Dim and Dark @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination} (but not Pitch Darkness).

Mindless

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Mindless]{Link to Special Ability}

This creature is immune to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Puppet]{Puppet}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunt}, and any attempts to manipulate it with any abilities that @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Tests} its @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Smarts}.

Natural weapons

Creatures with natural weapons such as fangs, claws, or horns may attack with any or all of them using their @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} skill. Damage is stated for character races and beasts in their various descriptions.

Creatures with natural weapons are always considered armed. This means they aren’t @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Unarmed Defender} and foes fighting with @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Two Weapons} gain no advantage against them. Here are additional notes for each type of attack:

  • BITE: The creature may bite a target it has grappled (most attackers can only crush their prey, see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Grappling}).
  • CLAWS: +2 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (climbing) rolls on any rough or soft surface (not sheer steel, glass, etc.).
  • HORNS: Add +4 damage at the end of one @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} action in which it runs, moves at least 5″(10 yards), and successfully hits with its horns.

Night vision

Some creatures thrive in the darkest depths of the night— or in underground caverns and dungeons. Creatures with night vision ignore all @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination} penalties.

Pack Tactics

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Pack Tactics]{Link to Special Ability}

This creature applies its @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Gang Up} bonus to damage rolls as well as the usual bonus to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting}.

Paralysis

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Paralysis]{Link to Special Ability}

Paralyzing poisons are covered under Poison, below. Other creatures might paralyze their victims with magic, electricity, or other sources. Victims @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} by a paralyzing effect are @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned} but can't attempt to recover for d4+1 rounds (or longer if otherwise specified).

Poison

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Poison]{Link to Special Ability}

Snakes, spiders, and other creatures inject poisonous venom via bite or scratch. To do so, the thing must cause at least a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} result to the victim, who then makes a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll modified by the strength of the poison (listed in parentheses after the creature’s Poison ability). Effects of failure are described in more detail in the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{Hazards} section.

Pounce

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Pounce]{Link to Special Ability}

Predators often pounce on their prey to best bring their mass and claws to bear. If a creature with pounce makes a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wild Attack}, it adds +4 to its damage instead of +2 to one successful @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} attack.

Regeneration

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Regeneration]{Link to Special Ability}

Hydras, trolls, vampires, and other legendary creatures can Regenerate their injuries.

Regeneration comes in two types: Fast and Slow.

  • Fast: @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} creatures make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll every round— even after they’ve been @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}. @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Success} heals one Wound (or removes Incapacitated status), and a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise} heals an additional Wound. Wounds caused by some types of damage, listed in the creature’s description, do not regenerate but may still heal naturally. Trolls cannot regenerate Wounds caused by flame, for example.
  • Slow: The creature makes a natural @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03healing0000000]{healing} roll once per day.

Rending Attack

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Rending Attack]{Link to Special Ability}

Some creatures have especially vicious claws or weapons. Victims @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} by a rending attack are bleeding and must make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll as a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{free action} at the beginning of their next turn.

Failure causes one Wound and the victim must make another Vigor roll next turn. @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Success} means the victim doesn't suffer a Wound, but must make a Vigor roll again next turn. A @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise} stops the bleeding and no further rolls are required from that attack.

A successful @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Healing]{Healing} roll also stops the bleeding.

Resilient/Very Resilient

Some creatures, such as ogres or dire versions of common animals on Golarion, are tough to put down.

Resilient Extras can take one @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound} before they’re @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}, Very Resilient Extras can take two. @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Cards} can’t be Resilient or Very Resilient. The abilities exist to bring select Extras a little closer to the heroes and villains who lead them.

Size

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Size]{Link to Special Ability}

Size grants a bonus to Toughness (or penalty for small creatures) and is a guide to the typical @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Strength} of creatures in that general range.

Size is generally based on mass, but exceptions exist for extremely large but weak creatures, small but strong beings, etc.

Scale Modifiers are explained under @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Size & Scale}.

Additional Wounds: Large creatures can take an additional @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound}, Huge can take two, and Gargantuan three. The maximum Wound penalty is always three. This stacks with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Resilient]{Resilient/Very Resilient}.

Such creatures typically have @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Reach} equal to the additional @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} granted by Size.

Stun

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Stun]{Link to Special Ability}

A creature with this ability often has an electrical attack, mild toxin, mind lash, or similar @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping}. When it successfully hits a character (even if it causes no damage), she must make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll minus any listed penalties or be @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned}.

Swallow whole

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Swallow Whole]{Link to Special Ability}

Certain massive creatures with gigantic maws can swallow their prey whole. This usually requires a successful @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Bite} attack. See the creature’s description for details and how prey might escape this dire fate!

Swat

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Swat]{Link to Special Ability}

The creature has learned how to deal with pesky creatures smaller than itself. It ignores up 4 points of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Scale} penalties when attacking with certain abilities listed in its description (and only those specific abilities).

Tentacles

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Tentacles]{Link to Special Ability}

The creature has a number of “tentacle actions” specified in its description (usually 2 or 4) it may use once per turn. All of a creature's tentacle @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{actions} count as one of its three potential actions for the turn, and must stem from the tentacle in some way— usually a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting}, or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Grappling} attack (GM’s call). A giant octopus with four tentacle actions, for example, could make four attacks as one action and still have two actions left over.

If the creature is a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Card}, it rolls its @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Die} with each tentacle action as usual.

If the being performs other actions on its turn, such as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunting} or casting a spell, these and the tentacle actions are affected by the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Multi-Action} penalty as usual.

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Grappling} rolls made with tentacles get a +2 bonus, and its crushing attack causes the creature’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Strength} in damage unless otherwise listed.

Severing a tentacle is a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Called Shot}. If damage exceeds the creature’s Toughness, the limb is severed and the monster is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}. If it was already @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}, it takes a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound}.

Trample

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Trample]{Link to Special Ability}

Elephants, rhinoceroses, and other large creatures can trample smaller victims under foot when moving at least 5″ (10 yards) in a straight line. This usually applies only when the opponents are at least two @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{sizes} smaller. See the creature's description for any special conditions or effects.

The creature makes a single attack at −2 and applies it to all victims in its movement path. Those it tramples may make an attack on it after if passes if desired (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Withdrawing From Melee}), unless it has @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Extraction]{Extraction} or a similar ability.

Undead

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Undead]{Link to Special Ability}

Zombies, skeletons, and similar physical horrors are particularly difficult to destroy. In most cases, undead creatures are Evil, but there are exceptions. Below are the benefits of being such an abomination.

  • Add +2 to Toughness and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Spirit} rolls to recover from being @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}, ignore additional damage from @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Called Shots}, ignore 1 point of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound} penalties, don’t breathe or eat and are immune to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{disease} and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{poison}, don’t @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03healing0000000]{Bleed Out}, ignore penalties for @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination} up to 10″, and can only be healed with magical @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Healing]{Healing}.

Unstoppable

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Unstoppable]{Link to Special Ability}

The creature has strong will, magical protections, or great mass. It takes a maximum of one Wound per attack no matter how many @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} would normally be caused (after @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Soak rolls} are made). Certain Weaknesses or magic items ignore this ability, as does an attacker acting on a Joker.

Wall Walker

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Wall Walker]{Link to Special Ability}

A wall walker’s movement rate when walking on walls is its standard @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Movement}. It may run as usual when walking on walls unless the specific creature’s text says otherwise.

Weakness

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Weakness]{Link to Special Ability}

Some creatures can only be hurt by certain substances, are debilitated by sunlight or holy symbols, or might perish immediately if affected by some holy relic, rare object, or magical item. A Weakness not covered by @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Environmental Weakness]{Environmental Weakness} is listed here along with the specific rules and conditions required to trigger it.

Types

This Bestiary categorizes creatures within Thirteen distinct Types. These categories are referenced in other Savage Pathfinder rules.

  • Aberration: Rare creatures with bizarre anatomy, strange abilities, or other alien characteristics.
  • Animal: Any living vertebrate creature with no magical abilities and no innate language or culture. Smarts is relative to the animal world, as indicated by the (A) as a reminder of “animal intelligence.”
  • Construct: An artificially created object or creature.
  • Dragon: The family of legendary magical reptilian creatures, usually winged.
  • Fey: Supernatural creatures, usually humanoid in appearance, with connections to nature or some other fantastical realm.
  • Humanoid: Biped creatures, with a human-like head, torso and limbs. Humanoids usually possess language and form cultures.
  • Magical Beast: Similar to Animals, creatures of this type possess some kind of magical or supernatural ability.
  • Monstrous Humanoid: Similar to Humanoids, these creatures have some monstrous features or characteristics, as well as magical or beastly abilities.
  • Ooze: Mindless amorphous creatures, Oozes often consume resources and pose environmental hazards to other creature types.
  • Outsider: Although these creatures resemble other types, their origin, or perhaps their composition, comes from beyond the Material Plane.
  • Plant: Creatures composed of vegetation, different than regular plant life, which are considered objects.
  • Undead: A once-living creature reanimated by magical or supernatural force.
  • Vermin: Living invertebrate creatures, from insects, to arachnids, and arthropods.

Alignment

Like characters, creatures have an alignment of either Evil, Good, or Neutral. Each creature’s alignment is listed in parenthesis after the Type.

In general, most animals, constructs and vermin are Neutral, while most aberrations, outsiders, and undead are Evil. The alignments of Magical Beasts and Humanoids vary widely.

Bestiary

The following creatures are common throughout Golarion. See the Pathfinder for Savage Worlds Bestiary for additional fearsome foes and monsters.

Alligator/Crocodile

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Alligator/crocodile]{Link to Actor}

Alligators and crocodiles lurk in the wetlands of Golarion, usually freshwater but sometimes in brackish or saltwater. The statistics here represent an average specimen of either species. Much larger versions are often found in more remote areas.

Type: Animal (Neutral)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d10, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d6, Fighting d6, Intimidation d6, Notice d8, Stealth d8

Pace: 5; Parry: 5; Toughness: 10 (2)

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +2: Thick skin.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Aquatic]{Aquatic}: Pace 6.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Bite]{Bite}: Str+d6.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Low Light Vision]{Low Light Vision}: Gators and crocs ignore penalties for Dim and Dark @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination}.
  • Rollover: Gators and crocs grasp prey in their vice-like jaws and roll with them. If one of these large reptiles hits with a raise, its bonus damage is a d10 instead of a d6.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size} 2: Common gators are about 10′ long, thick, heavy, and weigh just under 750 lbs.

Bear

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Bear]{Link to Actor}

This entry covers the larger ursines, such as grizzlies, black bears, and polar bears. A favored tactic of all these bears is to grapple and bite with their fierce fangs.

Type: Animal (Neutral)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d8, Strength d12, Vigor d10

Skills: Athletics d6, Fighting d8, Intimidation d6, Notice d8, Stealth d6

Pace: 7; Parry: 6; Toughness: 11 (2)

Edges:@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Brute]{Brute}

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +2: Thick hide.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Bite] / @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Claws]{Claws}: Str+d6 AP 2.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Low Light Vision]{Low Light Vision}: Bears ignore penalties for Dim and Dark @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination}.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size} 2: These creatures can stand up to 8′ tall and weigh over 1,000 pounds.

Bird of Prey

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Bird Of Prey]{Link to Actor}

This profile covers eagles, hawks, and similar large birds of prey, collectively termed “raptors.” Their talons and hooked-beaks can rip through flesh with ease.

These nocturnal or diurnal hunters sometimes serve humanoid masters on Golarion. They prefer to seize and carry off smaller quarry, although some are known to attack livestock.

Type: Animal (Neutral)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d4−2, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d6, Notice d10, Stealth d8

Pace: 3; Parry: 5; Toughness: 3

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Bite] / @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Claws]{Claws}: Str+d4.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Flight]{Flight}: Raptors fly at a Pace of 24.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Low Light Vision]{Low Light Vision}: Birds of Prey ignore penalties for Dim and Dark @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination}.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size} −2 (Small): Falcons, eagles, and owls stand about 3’ tall with wingspans of 5’ or more.

Boar

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Boar]{Link to Actor}

This entry covers a variety of wild pigs. Typically, these creatures pose a danger only during their rutting season, or when defending themselves. Humanoids sometimes keep these omnivores as guards, warbeasts, or garbage disposals.

Type: Animal (Neutral)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d8, Strength d10, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d6, Fighting d6, Notice d6

Pace: 7; Parry: 5; Toughness: 7 (1)

Edges:—

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +1: Thick hide.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Low Light Vision]{Low Light Vision}: Boars ignore penalties for Dim and Dark @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination}.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Hardy]{Hardy}: A second @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} result doesnt cause a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound} to a wild boar.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Horns]{Tusks}: Str+d4 (counts as horns).

Cat, Large

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Cat, Large]{Link to Actor}

This profile covers a variety of big cats, from mountain lions, to leopards, and cheetahs.

Type: Animal (Neutral)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d6 (A), Spirit d8, Strength d8, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d6, Intimidation d6, Notice d6, Stealth d8, Survival d6

Pace: 8; Parry: 5; Toughness: 6

Edges:@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Frenzy]{Frenzy}

Special Abilities:

  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Bite] / @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Claws]{Claws}: Str+d6.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Low Light Vision]{Low Light Vision}: A large cat ignores penalties for Dim and Dark @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination}.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Pounce]{Pounce}: A large cat pounces on its prey to best bring their mass and claws to bear. If it makes a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wild Attack}, it adds +4 to its damage instead of +2.

Cat, Small

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Cat, Small]{Link to Actor}

This is an ordinary house cat, the sort that might be a familiar for a spellcaster, a Beast Master’s animal friend, or an alternate form for the shape change power.

Type: Animal (Neutral)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d8, Strength d4−3, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d8, Notice d6, Stealth d8

Pace: 6; Parry: 2; Toughness: 2

Edges:@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Acrobat]{Acrobat}

Special Abilities:

  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Bite] / @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Claws]{Claws}: Str.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Low Light Vision]{Low Light Vision}: Cats ignore penalties for Dim and Dark @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination}.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size} −3 (Very Small): Cats are typically less than a foot high.

Dog/Wolf

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Dog/wolf]{Link to Actor}

The stats below are for large attack dogs, as well as wolves, hyenas, and the like.

Type: Animal (Neutral)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d6 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d6, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d6, Notice d10, Stealth d8

Pace: 8; Parry: 5; Toughness: 4

Edges:@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Alertness]{Alertness}

Special Abilities:

  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Bite]{Bite}: Str+d4.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Low Light Vision]{Low Light Vision}: Canines ignore penalties for Dim and Dark @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination}.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size} −1: The heads of these canines come to an average human’s waist, and they weigh about 60 pounds.
  • Speed: d10 running die.

Horse, Light

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Horse, Light]{Link to Actor}

Riding horses compromise speed with carrying capacity. The smaller pony version is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size} 1 and Strength d10.

If trained for combat, increase @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} to d6.

Type: Animal (Neutral)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d12, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d4, Notice d6

Pace: 12; Parry: 4; Toughness: 8

Edges:@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Fleet-Footed.]{Fleet-Footed.}

Special Abilities:

  • Kick: Str+d4, to the front or rear as desired.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size} 2: Typical quarter horse of about 1,000 lbs.

Horse, Heavy

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Horse, Heavy]{Link to Actor}

These beasts are meant for labor or carrying heavy riders. The smaller pony version is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size} 2, Strength d10, and Vigor d8.

If trained for combat, increase @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} to d6.

Type: Animal (Neutral)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d12+1, Vigor d10

Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d4, Notice d6

Pace: 10; Parry: 4; Toughness: 10

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • Kick: Str+d4, to the front or rear as desired.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size} 3: A draft horse of about 1,000 to 1,500 lbs.

Lion

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Lion]{Link to Actor}

The kings of the jungle are fierce predators, particularly in open grassland where their prey cannot seek refuge. The females in a group are the primary hunters, and they typically hunt together. That said, they will hunt alone, and a solitary lion is a dangerous foe.

Type: Animal (Neutral)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d6 (A), Spirit d10, Strength d12, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d10, Fighting d8, Intimidation d6, Notice d8, Stealth d10

Pace: 8; Parry: 6; Toughness: 7

Edges:@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Frenzy]{Frenzy (Imp)}

Special Abilities:

  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Bite] / @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Claws]{Claws}: Str+d6 AP 2.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Low Light Vision]{Low Light Vision}: Lions ignore penalties for Dim and Dark @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination}.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Pounce]{Pounce}: Lions pounce on their prey to best bring their mass and claws to bear. If a lion makes a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wild Attack}, it adds +4 to its damage instead of +2.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size} 1: Typical males are about 400 pounds.

Mule

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Mule]{Link to Actor}

Mules are a cross between a donkey and a horse, and are usually used to haul heavy goods or pull wagons.

Like any good pet, the GM should give the mule a little personality. The expression “stubborn as a mule” certainly comes to mind.

Type: Animal (Neutral)

Attributes: Agility d4, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d8, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d4, Notice d4

Pace: 6; Parry: 2; Toughness: 8

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • Kick: Str.
  • Ornery: Mules are contrary creatures. Characters must subtract 1 from their Riding rolls when riding them.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size} 2: Mules are stocky creatures usually weighing under 1000 pounds.

Shark

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Shark]{Link to Actor}

These statistics cover the likes of bull sharks and white tips. These dangerous predators swim throughout the seas of Golarion.

Type: Animal (Neutral)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d8 (d10 for bull shark), Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d8, Notice d12, Stealth d8

Pace: —; Parry: 6; Toughness: 8 (1)

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +1: Rubbery hide.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Aquatic]{Aquatic}: Pace 10.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Bite]{Bite}: Str+d6, AP 2.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size} 1: Sharks weigh up to 500 pounds.

Skeleton, Human

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Skeleton, Human]{Link to Actor}

Type: Undead (Evil)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d4, Spirit d4, Strength d6, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d6, Fighting d6, Intimidation d6, Notice d4, Shooting d6

Pace: 6; Parry: 5; Toughness: 7

Edges: —

Gear: Varies.

Special Abilities:

  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Claws]{Claws}: Str+d4.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Fearless]{Fearless}: Skeletons are immune to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04fear0000000000]{Fear} and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation}.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Undead]{Undead}: +2 Toughness; +2 to recover from being @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}; no additional damage from Called Shots; ignores 1 point of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound} penalties; doesn’t breathe; immune to disease and poison; ignore penalties for @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination} up to 10″.

Snake, Constrictor

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Snake, Constrictor]{Link to Actor}

Pythons, boa constrictors, and other snakes over 15′ long are rarely deadly to man in the real world because they aren’t particularly aggressive. On Golarion, however, such snakes might be guardians, familiars, or just plain carnivorous hunters.

Type: Animal (Neutral)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d8, Strength d8, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d6, Fighting d6, Notice d10, Stealth d6

Pace: 4; Parry: 5; Toughness: 5

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Bite]{Bite}: Str.
  • Constrict: +2 to Athletics and Strength rolls made to grapple.

Snake, Venomous

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Snake, Venomous]{Link to Actor}

These stats cover a variety of medium-@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Sized} snakes with extremely deadly poison. Such venomous snakes usually live solitary lives, although it’s possible to stumble into a nest of poisonous vipers.

Type: Animal (Neutral)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d4−2, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d6, Fighting d8, Notice d12, Stealth d8

Pace: 4; Parry: 6; Toughness: 2

Edges:@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Quick]{Quick}

Special Abilities:

  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Bite]{Bite}: Str+2.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Poison]{Poison}: The GM chooses what kind of poison the viper injects (see @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Poison]{Poison}).
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size} −3 (Very Small): Most venomous snakes are 4–6′ in length, but only a few inches thick.

Swarm

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Swarm]{Link to Actor}

A swarm is typically a mass of tiny creatures— from biting ants to stinging wasps to filthy rats. They cover an area equal to a Large, Medium, or Small Blast Template and attack everyone within it every round. When a swarm is Incapacitated it’s effectively dispersed.

Swarms aren’t intelligent enough to do anything but move and bite and shouldn’t take @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Multi-Actions}, make @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Tests}, etc.

Type: Animal (Neutral)

Attributes: Agility d10, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d12, Strength d8, Vigor d10

Skills: Notice d6

Pace: 10; Parry: 4; Toughness: 7

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • Bite or Sting: Swarms inflict hundreds of tiny bites or stings every round, hitting automatically (unless @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}) and causing 2d4 damage to everyone in the template at the end of their turn. Damage is applied to the least armored location.
  • Split: Some swarms split into two smaller swarms when @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} (GM’s call). Reduce the Blast Template one size after a Wound; Small swarms are destroyed.
  • Swarm: +2 to recover from being @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}, Parry +2. Swarms are composed of many small creatures, so cutting and piercing weapons do no real damage. Area effect attacks work normally, and a character can stomp to inflict his Strength in damage each round. Some swarms (bees, hornets, birds) may be foiled by total immersion in water.

Town/City Guard

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Town/City Guard]{Link to Actor}

Individuals charged with maintaining law and order, or keeping the peace, are covered by this profile.

Their attributes and skills may vary depending on the locality they serve. Their gear represents likely weapons and armor— which also varies depending on the climate, size of the settlement and other circumstances.

Type: Humanoid (Any)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d6, Spirit d6, Strength d6, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d4, Common Knowledge d4, Fighting d6, Intimidation d4, Notice d6, Shooting d6, Shooting d4, Stealth d4

Pace: 6; Parry: 4 or 6 (shield); Toughness: 7 (2)

Hindrances: —

Edges:@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Soldier]{Soldier}

Gear: Short sword (Str+d6), light crossbow (Range 10/20/40, Damage 2d6, AP 2), leather armor (+2), medium shield (Parry +2, Cover −2).

Townsfolk

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Townsfolk]{Link to Actor}

This profile covers everything from farmers, to merchants, and artisans. They are everyday folks, not soldiers or town guards.

Their attributes and skills vary as needed. For example, artisans probably have Repair d6, while a stable boy probably has Riding d4. Their gear represents only what might be in hand whenever any unplanned combat takes place. Townsfolk rarely wear armor.

Type: Humanoid (Any)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d6, Spirit d6, Strength d6, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d4, Common Knowledge d4, Fighting d4, Notice d6, Shooting d4, Stealth d6

Pace: 6; Parry: 4; Toughness: 5

Hindrances: —

Edges: —

Gear: Knife (Str+d4), club (Str+d4), or improvised weapons (Str+d4).

Zombie, Human

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Zombie, Human]{Link to Actor}

This profile covers most any man-sized humanoid zombie.

Type: Undead (Evil)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4, Spirit d4, Strength d6, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d4, Fighting d6, Intimidation d6, Notice d4, Shooting d6

Pace: 4; Parry: 5; Toughness: 7

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Bite] / @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Claws]{Claws}: Str+d4.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Fearless]{Fearless}: Zombies are immune to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04fear0000000000]{Fear} and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation}.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Undead]{Undead}: +2 Toughness; +2 to recover from being @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}; no additional damage from @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Called Shots}; ignores 1 point of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} penalties; doesn’t breathe; immune to disease and poison; ignore penalties for @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination} up to 10″.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Weakness]{Weakness} (Head): @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Called Shots} to a zombie’s head do the usual +4 damage.

Making Characters.name: Making Characters
Making Characters.text:
Characters

Your journey into the world of Golarion begins with selecting or creating a hero. If you want to jump right in and play a pregenerated character, look in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Class Edges}. You’ll find representatives of all 11 core character concepts presented there. Each is based on the original Pathfinder “classes” and are ready-to-play immediately. They come complete with languages, starting gear, and even a track of suggested @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01advancement000]{Advances}.

Grab a character sheet from our website and copy over their statistics, or customize whatever you’re comfortable with to make them your own.

We also make a range of pregenerated “Archetypes” presented in handy card format. You’ll find these on our website in both print and PDF. They’re great to hand out at the game table for a new group so they can see the diversity of character types available and choose one that interests them. They also provide inspiration for creating your own custom character, which is described in detail on the pages that follow.

Making Characters


Concept

Begin your adventure by thinking about the kind of character you want to play. Do you want to try a wily @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Wizard]{wizard}, a burly @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Barbarian]{barbarian}, a tricksy @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Rogue]{rogue}, or some original idea you’ve come up with yourself? The Savage Worlds rules allow you to create most anything.

For the world of Savage Pathfinder, take a close look at the Class Edges subsection in Edges @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{here}. These special abilities form the foundation of the typical player character types found in Golarion. Keep these in mind as you follow the rest of these steps so you can build toward those if you want to play a traditional Pathfinder-style hero.

Rank

“Ranks” reflect a character’s competence and experience. They provide balance between players and grant access to more powerful abilities as one “Advances.” A character begins at Novice Rank and works upward from there. Advances are given out after one or more game sessions. The GM has more detailed information in the Advancement section @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01advancement000]{here}.

Only player characters use Ranks— Game Master-controlled characters and creatures don’t (we’ll tell you more about this later).

Rank
Advances Rank
0–3 Novice
4–7 Seasoned
8–11 Veteran
12–15 Heroic
16+ Legendary

Starting With Experienced Characters

If the Game Master wants to start a game with more experienced characters, or you're making a replacement for a fallen hero, you should still make a Novice starting profile and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01advancement000]{Advance} it from there. This ensures characters are balanced just as if they had gained experience normally.

Additional goods, equipment, or other assets must be determined by the Game Master. As a quick rule of thumb, Seasoned heroes have 10,000 gold pieces worth of goods and magic items, Veteran characters get 40,000, Heroic 150,000, and Legendary 500,000.

Ancestry

This core rule book comes with seven recommended ancestries to use when creating player characters. See ancestries for more info @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01ancestries0000]{here}.

Hindrances

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrances0000]{Hindrances} are flaws, drawbacks, or dark secrets drawn from a character’s backstory. They provide up to four additional “Hindrance points” you can use to enhance your hero during character creation.

Taking Hindrances not only helps you define and roleplay your hero, but also allows you to increase his @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{attribute or skill} points, take @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edges}, or have additional gold to buy better adventuring gear.

A Major @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrances0000]{Hindrance} is worth 2 Hindrance points, and a Minor is worth 1. A hero could thus take two Major Hindrances, four Minor, or any combination that adds up to 4 character points. (You can take more Hindrances if you want but the maximum benefit is 4 points!)

For 2 Hindrance points you can:

  • Raise an attribute one die type, or
  • Choose an Edge

For 1 Hindrance point you can:

  • Gain another skill point, or
  • Start play with an additional 600 gold pieces.

Traits

Characters are defined by attributes and skills, collectively called “Traits.” Attributes and skills are ranked by die types, typically from d4 to d12, with d6 being the average for adult humans. Higher is better!

Attributes typically govern how fast your skills can increase, and are used for passive effects such as resisting spells or recovering from injuries.

Attributes

Every character starts with a d4 in each of five attributes: Agility, Smarts, Spirit, Strength, and Vigor (discussed in more detail in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Traits}).

You then have 5 character points to increase your attributes. Raising a d4 to a d6, for example, costs 1 point.

Attribute Limit: No attribute may be raised above a d12 unless an ancestral ability or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edge} says otherwise. Each increase beyond a d12 adds a +1 modifier. Increasing a d12 Strength two steps or “die types,” for example, gives your hero a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Strength} score of d12+2.

Skills

Skills are learned abilities such as firing weapons, hand-to-hand combat, scientific knowledge, professional aptitudes, and so on.

Skills in Savage Pathfinder are very broad to keep the action simple and straightforward. The @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} skill, for example, covers all types of bows and crossbows. The @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} skill covers thrown weapons, as well as grappling, swimming, and climbing. Detailed customization comes in the form of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edgesummarie00]{Edges}.

Core Skills: Five skills are marked with a red star in the list for skills in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Traits}: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Common Knowledge]{Common Knowledge}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion}, and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Stealth]{Stealth}. These are “innate” abilities most adult adventurers have. Unless an ancestral ability, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edge}, or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrances0000]{Hindrance} says otherwise, your character starts with a d4 in each of these five core skills.

Buying Skills: After core skills are assigned, you have 12 additional character points to raise core skills or buy and raise new skills as you see fit.

Each die type costs 1 point (starting at d4) as long as the skill is equal to or less than the attribute it’s linked to (listed beside the skill in parentheses, in the list starting in the Skills subsection in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Traits}). If you exceed the linked attribute, the cost becomes 2 points per die type.

Languages: Your character starts with Common and knows additional languages equal to half her @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Smarts} die type. Typical choices are listed with each ancestry. See Languages in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Traits} for more information.

Skill Limit: Skills may not be increased above d12 during character creation unless the character’s ancestry starts with the skill at d6. If the skill starts with a d6, increase her maximum to d12+1. Elves in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01ancestries0000]{Ancestries} start with a d6 in @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice}, for example, which means their Notice skill may be increased to d12+1.

Derived Statistics

Your character sheet contains a few other statistics you need to fill in, described below.

Pace is how fast your character moves in tactical situations like combat. Standard Pace is 6, which means six tabletop inches per game round. Each inch is two yards (6 feet) in the real world. @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Movement} is explained in detail in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Combat}.

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Parry} is equal to 2 plus half your character’s @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} die type (a total of 2 if a character doesn’t have Fighting), plus any bonuses for shields or certain weapons. This is the Target Number (TN) to hit your hero in hand-to-hand combat.

For Fighting skills higher than d12, such as d12+1, add half the fixed modifier, rounded down. For instance, Fighting d12+1 grants a Parry of 8, while Fighting d12+2 results in a Parry of 9.

Size: A hero’s default @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Size} is 0 unless altered by ancestral abilities, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edges}, or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrances0000]{Hindrances}. It cannot be less than −1 or more than +3.

Toughness is your hero’s damage thres­hold. Damage rolls that equal or exceed this number @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{cause harm} (explained later in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Rules}).

Toughness is 2 plus half your hero’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor}, plus @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02armor000000000]{Armor} (use the armor worn on his torso. Vigor over a d12 is calculated just like @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Parry}, above.

Edges

Attributes and skills are a character’s basic statistics, but what really makes individuals different are their @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edgesummarie00]{Edges}.

In Pathfinder for Savage Worlds, every character starts with a Class Edge for free. The character must qualify for the Edge as usual. (If a player doesn’t want to take a Class Edge, she may take a free Background or Professional Edge she qualifies for instead.)

Characters get additional Edges by taking @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrancesum00]{Hindrances}, from racial abilities (such as Humans’ Adaptability), or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01advancement000]{Advances} once play begins.

A comprehensive list of Edges for use in Savage Pathfinder is available @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{here}.

Gear

Player characters have 300 gold pieces (or “gp”) to purchase any of the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02personalweap00]{weapons}, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02armor000000000]{armor}, and adventuring gear presented in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{the Gear Chapter}.

This might represent everything the character owns or it may represent only “adventuring” gear, with the hero’s more mundane belongings stored at a home or elsewhere.

Background

Finish your new hero by filling in any additional history or background you see fit. Ask yourself why she’s where she is and what her goals are. Where does she live? Does she have any close friends or family who might be relevant to the game? Why did she join the Pathfinders?

Or just start playing and fill in these details as they become important and you walk around in her shoes a bit.

You might also want to talk to the other players. Maybe your characters know each other right from the start. Or you might collectively decide to optimize your group a bit and ensure you’ve got a good assortment of skills and abilities. If so, make sure you’re playing what you want to play. There’s no point in being the party’s healer if that’s not a role you care to play.

Deities and alignment

The conflict between Good and Evil is a core theme of any Savage Pathfinder game. Typically, heroes fight for Good, but not always.

Alignments in Savage Pathfinder indicate the general moral compass of a person, creature or organization. Where alignment is listed, it is a tool for the Game Master to identify the broad outlook of that entity, and how it may interact with others, including the adventurers. When choosing an alignment for your character, you decide what ethical path he will follow, guided by the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edgesummarie00]{Edges} and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrancesum00]{Hindrances} you chose to define him. Unless your GM specifically agrees, you cannot choose Evil as your alignment.

Some character concepts require choosing a deity or “Domain” that governs powers and certain abilities. Likewise, the player’s choice of Hindrances can involve a Deity or a cause, such as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Vow]{Vow} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Code of Honor]{Code of Honor}. Deities have a listed alignment, either Good, Neutral, or Evil to indicate the general philosophy of the deity and her followers. Of course, adherents to a particular faith might not necessarily share the same outlook as the deity's alignment. Terrible deeds might be perpetrated in the name of a good or merciful god. You can find more information on domains and deities in the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edges} section.

Character creation summary

Concept

  • Start with a general idea of what you want to play. Review the classes and the Iconic Path character profiles for ideas.

Ancestry

  • Choose your character’s ancestry from the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01ancestries0000]{ancestries} entry and apply any special abilities it grants.

Hindrances

  • Choose up to 4 points of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrances0000]{Hindrances} (Major Hindrances are worth 2, Minor are worth 1).
    • For 2 Hindrance points you can raise an attribute one die type, or choose an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edge}.
    • For 1 Hindrance point you can gain another skill point, or gain 600gp in additional starting funds.

Attributes

  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Attributes} start at d4. You have 5 points to distribute among them. Each step costs 1 point.
  • Attributes may not be raised beyond d12 unless the hero’s ancestry or class states otherwise.

Skills

  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Common Knowledge]{Common Knowledge}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion}, and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Stealth]{Stealth} are core @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{skills} and start at d4 for free. Any given skill might be increased because of ancestry.
  • You have 12 points to put into these or any other skills. Each die type costs 1 point up to and equal to the linked attribute; then 2 points per die type after that.
  • Your character knows Common plus a number of starting Languages equal to half your character’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Smarts} die type. A Smarts of d6, for example, gives you three additional starting languages. Typical choices are listed with each ancestry.

Derived Statistics

  • Standard @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Pace} is 6 and may be adjusted by ancestral abilities, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edges}, or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrances0000]{Hindrances}.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Parry} is 2 plus half of Fighting.
  • Toughness is 2 plus half of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor}, plus any @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02armor000000000]{Armor}. Track the amount of armor in parentheses like this— Toughness: 11 (2). This means 2 points of the total 11 Toughness comes from Armor. An @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Armor Piercing (AP)} attack could bypass those 2 points but not the other 9.

Edges

  • All characters get a Class Edge for free (or a Background or Professional Edge if desired).
  • Use any leftover @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrances0000]{Hindrance} points to take @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edges} if you like.
  • Each Edge costs 2 Hindrance points.

Gear

  • Purchase up to 300 gp worth of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{equipment}.

Background

  • Unless the Game Master says otherwise, your character’s basic Alignment is Good or Neutral for purposes of certain@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edgesummarie00]{Edges}, abilities, and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powers00000001]{powers}. Beyond that, who is she? Where does she come from? Does she have any family? Does she worship any of Golarion’s major deities?

Ancestries.name: Ancestries
Ancestries.text:
Ancestries

Savage Pathfinder includes seven recommended ancestries for use in character creation, along with abilities that reflect the most common or iconic virtues and drawbacks of each.

Note that the following descriptions allude to a lot of rules we haven’t explained yet. Just skim them for now and come back once you have a grasp on the rest of the game.

Dwarves

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Dwarf]{See Dwarves here}.
