This leader has proven herself time and time again, gaining the respect of all those who fight by her side.

Any Leadership Edge that says it applies only to Extras now applies to Wild Cards (including the player characters) as well.

Tactician

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Tactician]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Smarts d8+, Command, Battle d6+

The commander has a natural grasp of small unit tactics and can take advantage of rapidly changing situations.

A Tactician is dealt an extra Action Card each round of combat— kept separate from his own cards. At the start of the round, he may discard it or give it to any one allied Extra in Command Range. The player or GM controlling the receiving character can decide whether to accept and replace her current Action Card, or discard it.

Surprise: Tacticians don’t get their extra card if Surprised, but they can give it to an ally who’s Surprised if they like!

Master Tactician

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Master Tactician]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Veteran, Tactician

The Tactician now gets a total of two extra Action Cards to distribute each round.

Power Edges

Power Edges are the key to unlocking the true potential of those with Arcane Backgrounds. They can mean the difference between an apprentice with a few abilities and a master of magic or divine energies!

Arcane Armor

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Arcane Armor]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Armor Interference

Your Armor Interference counts as one level higher (so a character increasing their Armor Interference (Any) to (Light) could wear Light armor with no penalty).

Artificer

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Artificer]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Arcane Background (Any)

Those who tangle with supernatural forces sometimes find ways to imbue powers into items. They may turn an ordinary blade into a magic sword, grant powerful potions to their friends, or even bless holy relics with divine grace.

Artificers can create Arcane Devices and give them to their allies. See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05arcanedevice00]{Arcane Devices}. Where possible, the device reflects the forger’s background. A bard’s Arcane Devices are works of art, such as a singing sword, a magical instrument, an epic poem, etc.

Channeling

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Channeling]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Arcane Background (Any)

When the character gets a raise on her arcane skill roll (or roll to activate or use an arcane device), she reduces its Power Point cost by 1. This can take it to 0.

Concentration

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Concentration]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Arcane Background (Any) or Mystic Powers (Any)

Through training and focus, the caster is extremely efficient in channeling arcane forces. The base Duration of any non-Instant power is doubled. This includes maintaining powers as well.

Holy/Unholy Warrior

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Holy/Unholy Warrior]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Arcane Background (Any) or Mystic Powers (Any), Vow (to your Deity)

Believers face grave dangers in service to their divine patrons. To survive such hardships, the forces of good (or evil) grant miracles and the ability to turn their favor into supernatural protection.

After making a Soak roll, the chosen may add +1 to the total for each Power Point spent, to a maximum of +4.

New Powers

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.New Powers]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Arcane Background (Any)

An arcane character may learn two new powers by choosing this Edge (which may be taken multiple times). He may choose from any powers of his Rank or lower normally available to his particular Arcane Background.

A character can add a new Trapping on a power she already has instead of gaining a new one. She might add an ice Trapping to her existing fire @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Bolt]{bolt}, for example, so she could switch between ice and fire Trappings freely.

If a wizard takes this Edge, he may choose to learn two powers, as usual, plus a bonus third power, if he has discovered one contained in spellbooks or scrolls he has acquired. The wizard transcribes all three new powers into his spellbook and the original scrolls or spellbooks from which he gleaned his knowledge are added to his repository of notes and research in case he has to make a replacement spellbook in the future.

Power Points

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Arcane Background (Any) or Mystic Powers (Any)

Wizards, sorcerers, and other arcane types always want more power. This Edge grants them an additional 5 Power Points.

Power Points may be selected more than once, but only once per Rank. It may be taken as often as desired at Legendary Rank, but each grants only 2 additional points.

Power Surge

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Surge]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Wild Card, Novice, Arcane Background (Any), arcane skill d8+

The character recovers 10 Power Points when his Action Card is a Joker. This may not exceed his usual limit.

Soul Drain

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Soul Drain]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Arcane Background (Any) or Mystic Powers (Any), Spirit d8+

Once per day, Soul Drain allows a character to take a level of Fatigue to recover up to five Power Points as a limited free action. Or she can take two levels of Fatigue (Exhaustion) to recover up to 10 Power Points. She cannot render herself @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated} in this way.

Prestige Edges

Prestige Edges build on other Edges, classes, and skills to provide unique talents possessed by a rare few.

A character may only choose a new core Prestige Edge once per Rank (instead of a core Class Edge), and once every four Advances at Legendary Rank. Advanced Edges (the level II and III Edges listed below) are not subject to this restriction.

Arcane Archer

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Arcane Archer]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Arcane Background (Any) or Mystic Powers (Any), @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} d8+

An arcane archer uses magical energies to amplify his arrows or bolts. He may automatically grant one "quality" into any arrow he fires (designated per shot).

The first two qualities an archer learns are:

Enhance: The archer's arrow adds +1 to Shooting and damage.

Trapping: The arrow has an environmental Trapping such as fire, cold, darkness, etc.

Arcane Archer II

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Arcane Archer II]{Link to Journal Entry}

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Arcane Archer II]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Veteran, Arcane Archer

The archer gains two new qualities:

Phase Arrow: Once per encounter, the archer may fire an arrow directly through any non-magical barriers, ignoring penalties for Cover or Concealment.

Hail of Arrows: Once per encounter, the archer may enchant an arrow so it splits into many when fired, raining down in a Large Blast Template. Everyone inside the template is subject to the attack roll— roll damage separately.

Arcane Archer III

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Arcane Archer III]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Heroic, Arcane Archer II

The archer gains two new qualities:

Imbue: Once per turn, the archer can imbue any area effect power into an arrow, "casting" the spell with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} and using his bow's Range in place of the power's Range. The spell's area of effect is centered where the arrow lands, even if it must normally be centered on the caster. If the arrow misses, the spell fails. Imbued spells can't be Shorted or use the Range modifier.

Death Arrow: Once per day, the archer can fire a fearsome arrow thrumming with deadly energy. A target Shaken or Wounded by the arrow must make a Vigor roll or die! Death arrows have no effect on constructs or undead.

Arcane Trickster

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Arcane Trickster]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Arcane Background (Any) or Mystic Powers (Any), Sneak Attack ability, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Thievery]{Thievery} d8+

These prodigious thieves blend subtle aspects of the arcane with the cunning of sleight of hand and misdirection.

Ranged Legerdemain: The trickster can use his Thievery at a Range of 5” (10 yards) or less at a −2 penalty. Any object manipulated at range must weigh less than 5 pounds.

Impromptu Attack: Once per encounter, the trickster may use her Sneak Attack ability even if a foe isn’t Vulnerable or subject to the Drop.

Arcane Trickster II

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Arcane Trickster II]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Arcane Trickster

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Arcane Trickster II]{Link to Journal Entry}

Invisible Thief: Once per day, as a free action, the character may cast @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Invisibility]{invisibility} for a base cost of 1 Power Point. No arcane skill roll is required, and it's cast as if with a raise. The trickster may use other Power Modifiers or maintain the spell with her own Power Points as usual.

This Edge doesn't grant the trickster the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Invisibility]{invisibility} spell; she must have it on her own.

Arcane Trickster III

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Arcane Trickster III]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Veteran, Arcane Trickster II

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Arcane Trickster III]{Link to Journal Entry}

Surprise Spells: The trickster’s attack spells benefit from her Sneak Attack ability.

Assassin

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Assassin]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Sneak Attack ability

Those with this Edge are adept at infiltration and cold, efficient murder. They consider themselves artisans, and their medium is death.

Death Attack: If the assassin strikes a living victim with the Drop and causes at least one Wound (after any Soaking), the foe must make a Vigor roll or die.

If the assassin Incapacitates or slays a victim he had the Drop on, the victim drops quietly and without a sound. It may even be a few moments before those nearby @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice} the situation, depending on the circumstances.

Assassin II

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Assassin II]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Veteran, Assassin

Hide in Plain Sight: The assassin may magically hide in plain sight. Treat this as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Invisibility]{invisibility} (−4), as long as the assassin doesn’t move or make noise.

Resistance to Poison: The assassin adds +4 to rolls made to resist poison.

Assassin III

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Assassin III]{Link to Journal Entry}Requirements: Heroic, Assassin II

Angel of Death: The slayer gains the mystical ability to charge her attack with lethal death energy. If she chooses to do so, a victim slain by her hand crumbles to dust and cannot be resurrected. She may do this no more than once per day.

Swift Death: Once per day, as a free action, an assassin gains the Drop over a foe of her choice, even if the target is completely aware of her presence.

Dragon Disciple

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Dragon Disciple]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Arcane Background (any) or Mystic Powers (Any), @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Occult]{Occult} d6+

Spellcasters who embrace their draconic heritage and learn to channel their abilities become fearsome warriors. They possess not only the repertoire of an accomplished sorcerer, but also the ability to unleash the furious power of dragons upon their foes.

Breath Attack: Once per encounter, as a limited action the dragon disciple may make a breath attack in a Cone Template. The attack causes 3d6 damage and may be Evaded.

The attack has one of the following effects, based on the type of dragon the character descends from: fire (victims may catch fire, see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{Hazards}), acid (lingering damage, see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{Power Modifiers}), electricity (+2 damage to those in metal armor), or cold (victim is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{Hindered} until the end of his next turn, see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{Power Modifiers}).

Dragon Disciple II

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Dragon Disciple II]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Veteran, Dragon Disciple

Wings: The dragon disciple’s body becomes more scaly, his eyes more feral, and he may even grow small horns. Eventually, scaly wings sprout from his back, granting him @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Flight]{Flight} (Pace 8).

Dragon Disciple III

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Dragon Disciple III]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Heroic, Dragon Disciple II

The disciple’s transformation is now complete— this permanently changes her Type to Dragon.

Dragon Form: Twice per day as a limited action, the dragon disciple may take the form of a dragon of her bloodline. This makes her Size 3, Strength d12, and Vigor d10. She has Armor 4, and her Bite/Claw attack is Str+d8, AP 2. Her wings grow to accommodate her form.

If she doesn't already have it, her dragon form also grants her environmental resistance common to her draconic heritage (electricity for blue, fire for red, etc.)

Her clothing, gear, and magic items meld into her form and provide no benefits. She can remain in this form for up to five minutes, and extend the Duration another five minutes by taking a level of Fatigue.

She may still speak and cast spells in dragon form.

Duelist

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Duelist]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Agility d8+, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} d8+

Duelists represent the pinnacle of elegant swordplay, parrying blows and countering their opponent’s actions with expert ripostes.

Surgical Strike: A duelist makes surgical strikes with one-handed piercing weapons with a Min Str of d6 or less, adding +2 to her damage total.

Parry: If the duelist hasn’t acted this turn, she may declare the Defend maneuver after an opponent declares a Fighting attack against her but before he rolls. She discards her current Action Card and her Parry bonus is +6 instead of +4 that turn.

Duelist II

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Duelist II]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Duelist

Crippling Strike: A foe Shaken or Wounded by the duelist reduces his Pace by 2 until healed. No foe can be subject to more than one crippling strike, and can’t be reduced below a Pace of 1.

Duelist III

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Duelist III]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Veteran, Duelist II

Deflect Arrows: The duelist can now deflect arrows, bolts, and thrown weapons. Enemies subtract 2 from @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (throwing) or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} rolls to hit him. This stacks with Dodge and similar abilities, and is ignored if the duelist is surprised, Bound, unaware of the attack, or can’t generally parry the projectiles.

Eldritch Knight

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Eldritch Knight]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Arcane Background (any) or Mystic Powers (Any), @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} d8+

Elite warriors who train in both the martial and arcane arts learn how to take extra advantage of their prowess in both. These versatile heroes, the Eldritch Knights, are usually characters who studied both the martial and arcane arts.

Eldritch Recharge: Anytime the knight gets a raise on a damaging attack roll (@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (throwing), Fighting, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting}, or arcane skill), he regains a Power Point.

Eldritch Knight II

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Eldritch Knight II]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Veteran, Eldritch Knight

Eldritch Strike: The knight can spend two Power Points after making an attack roll to increase its total by +2.

Eldritch Knight III

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Eldritch Knight III]{Eldritch Knight III}

Requirements: Heroic, Eldritch Knight II

Eldritch Strike (Imp): The knight can spend two Power Points after making a successful attack roll to increase that attack's damage by +2.

Loremaster

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Loremaster]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Smarts d8+, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Academics]{Academics} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Common Knowledge]{Common Knowledge} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Occult]{Occult} d8+

A gatherer of secrets and arcane lore, this character values the acquisition of intellectual insights above all else. Often obsessed by the written word, the loremaster knows better than any that knowledge is power.

Lore: She gets a free reroll when making Academics, Common Knowledge, Occult, or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Science]{Science} rolls.

Loremaster II

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Loremaster II]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Veteran, Loremaster

The loremaster gains special insight into those she’s traveled and adventured with.

Secret: With the Game Master’s consent, she may take one ability from any core Class Edge she doesn’t already have. She might take the druid’s Wilderness Stride ability, for example, the rogue’s Sneak Attack, or a cleric’s ability to Channel Energy.

This doesn’t confer any other Traits, Edges, or rules required to use the ability.

Loremaster III

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Loremaster III]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Heroic,
Loremaster II

Greater Lore: The loremaster learns two new powers from any of those available in the campaign. This may not be useful if a power depends on mechanics the loremaster can’t make use of, but she can still learn the spell if she likes.

Mystic Theurge

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Mystic Theurge]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, two Arcane Backgrounds with two different arcane skills

Mystic theurges place no boundaries on their magical abilities, whether they stem from the arcane or divine.

Combined Spells: A theurge can cast two spells as a limited action. The theurge must use two different arcane skills, declare her spells and all Power Modifiers as usual, then roll a die for each (the Wild Die can replace either). If the arcane skills have the same die type use different colored dice so you know which is which.

The cost of both spells must be paid separately, and effects from Critical Failure apply normally but don’t stack.

Example: A theurge casts bolt with Spellcasting (d8) and healing with Faith (d10). She rolls a d8, a d10, and her Wild die, which may take the place of either skill die. She casts both spells, spends the usual number of Power Points, and may use any Power Modifiers she wishes for each.

Mystic Theurge II

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Mystic Theurge II]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Veteran, Mystic Theurge

Spell Synergy: When the theurge uses her Combined Spells ability she reduces the cost of each spell by one Power Point (to a minimum of 1).

Mystic Theurge III

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Mystic Theurge III]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Heroic, Mystic Theurge II

Spell Synthesis: The character's Class Edge abilities can now be applied to all spells provided by any of her classes.

Pathfinder Chronicler

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Pathfinder Chronicler]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Survival]{Survival} d6+, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Common Knowledge]{Common Knowledge} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Occult]{Occult} d8+

Brave explorers and seekers of lost or forgotten knowledge, these heroes are quintessential adventurers. They travel the world searching for esoteric truths, magical and mundane relics, and unexplored vistas.

Pathfinding: The pathfinder increases the party’s speed by 10% when navigating to known or mapped locations. See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04travel00000000]{Travel}.

She also knows which paths are safest and where to exercise additional caution. If the Game Master is drawing for encounters and gets the Enemies result (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04travel00000000]{Travel}), the chronicler may make a Smarts roll at −2 to discard that card and replace it with the next card in the deck.

Pathfinder Chronicler II

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Pathfinder Chronicler II]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Pathfinder Chronicler

Epic Tales: The chronicler recites a moving and evocative tale. Once per session, while the party is resting, every Wild Card ally who hears the tale gains a Benny.

Pathfinder Chronicler III

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Pathfinder Chronicler III]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Veteran, Pathfinder Chronicler II

Call Down the Legends: Once per game week, the chronicler can magically summon five “shades” of great Golarion heroes who have gone before. The shades assume mortal form, have the profiles in the sidebar at right, and last for one hour.

Shades

The shades appear as silent, somewhat formless heroes of Golarion— elves, dwarves, humans, and others. They cannot be mistaken for living beings except in the most obscured conditions. They appear from darkness and vanish into it when their time on the mortal realm expires. They are physical while here, and have only a fraction of their true self’s abilities.

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4, Spirit d6, Strength d8, Vigor d8

Skills: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} d6, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} d8, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation} d6, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice} d4, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Stealth]{Stealth} d6

Pace: 6; Parry: 5; Toughness: 8 (2)

Hindrances: —

Edges: —

Gear: Leather armor (+2), long sword (Str+d8).

Special Abilities:

  • Construct: +2 to recover from being Shaken; don’t breathe; immune to poison and disease.
  • Fearless: Shades are immune to Fear and Intimidation.

Shadowdancer

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Shadowdancer]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Performance]{Performance} d6+ @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Stealth]{Stealth} d8+, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Thievery]{Thievery} d6+

Some characters prefer the shadows, embracing the advantages of darkness to become artists of deception and surprise.

Greater Darkvision: Strong connection to the plane of shadows allows the hero to see perfectly in any illumination up to 10" (20 yards), including magical darkness and ignoring all penalties resulting from it.

Shadowdancer II

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Shadowdancer II]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Shadowdancer

Shadow Cloak: Darkness envelops and protects its champion. She gets one free Soak attempt at −2 whenever she's Wounded in Dim or Dark Illumination. This does not count as spending a Benny.

Shadowdancer III

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Shadowdancer III]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Veteran, Shadowdancer II

Mystic Powers (Shadow Force): As a limited free action the shadowdancer can cast one of the following spells: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Blast]{Blast}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Illusion]{illusion}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Summon Ally]{summon ally}, or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Teleport]{teleport} (self only). All of these have a Shadow Trapping.

The shadowdancer has 10 dedicated Power Points that @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05activation0000]{recharge} normally. She automatically activates the power with success for its regular cost, or with a raise for an additional 2 Power Points. See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powers00000000]{Powers} for more information on specific spells. She may use applicable Power Modifiers if desired (at the usual cost).

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Blast]{Blast} still requires line of sight, but otherwise automatically hits as long as any part of the target is visible and in Range.

Mystic Powers doesn’t grant access to Edges requiring an Arcane Background. If the shadowdancer also has an Arcane Background, none of its Edges and abilities can be used with Mystic Powers (and vice-versa).

Professional Edges

Professional Edges reflect years of practice or experience in a particular trade, activity, or craft. In some cases they may also represent special blessings from higher powers as well.

Players may purchase Professional Edges after character creation, perhaps roleplaying the achievement by practicing the affected trade during downtime or in between adventures.

Stacking: Bonuses to the same Trait from different Professional Edges do not stack— apply only the highest.

Ace

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Ace]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Agility d8+

Aces are pilots and drivers who have a special affinity with their vehicle. They ignore two points of penalties to any @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Boating]{Boating}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Driving]{Driving}, or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Piloting]{Piloting} roll, and may spend Bennies to Soak damage for any vehicle they control or command, using the appropriate Boating, Driving, or Piloting skill instead of Vigor. Each success and raise negates a Wound.

Acrobat

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Acrobat]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Agility d8+, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} d8+

The Acrobat gets one free reroll on Athletics totals that involve balance, tumbling, or grappling. It doesn’t affect rolls to interrupt actions, climb, swim, or throw.

Combat Acrobat

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Combat Acrobat]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Acrobat

The tumbler leaps quickly about so that attacks against her are made at −1 as long as she’s aware of the attack, can reasonably move about, and isn’t suffering any Encumbrance or Minimum Strength penalties.

Born in the Saddle

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Born in the Saddle]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Agility d8+, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Riding]{Riding} d6+

Whether it’s on the back of fast horse or other more exotic mount, this hero feels more at home in the saddle than on her own two feet.

The Edge grants the hero one free reroll on all Riding rolls and increases her mount’s Pace by 2 and its running die one step.

Fix It

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Fix It]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Repair]{Repair} d8+

The hero is a natural with mechanical contraptions. She adds +2 to Repair rolls, and with a raise, halves the time normally required to fix something. This means if a particular Repair job says a raise repairs it in half the time, a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Fix It]{Fix It} can finish the job in one-quarter the time with a raise.

Investigator

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Investigator]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Smarts d8+, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Academics]{Academics} d8+

Investigators spend a great deal of time in vast libraries researching ancient legends, working the streets, or deducing Golarion’s greatest mysteries. They add +2 to Academics or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice} rolls made to sift through information, sift through stacks of papers, look through shelves of books for something of note, or spy obscured items from piles of junk or debris.

Jack-Of-All-Trades

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Jack-Of-All-Trades]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Smarts d10+

Through advanced schooling, book-learning, or just amazing intuitive perception, your hero has a talent for picking up skills on the fly. There’s little she can’t figure out given a little time and a dash of luck.

The character makes a Smarts roll as an action after observing or studying some subject. She gains a d4 in the relevant skill with success, or d6 with a raise. She may try again after an hour of study, trial and effort, or immersion if she fails or wants to try for a raise. This lasts until the character attempts to learn a different subject, whether she’s successful or not.

Scholar

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Scholar]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Smarts d8+

Learned professors, devoted students, and amateur enthusiasts spend great amounts of time and energy studying particular subjects. They become experts in these fields, and rarely fail to answer questions in their particular area of expertise.

Pick any one of the following skills: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Academics]{Academics}, Battle, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Occult]{Occult}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Science]{Science}, or a Smarts-based “knowledge”-type skill allowed in your game, and add +2 to the total whenever they’re used.

This Edge may be taken more than once if applied to different skills.

Soldier

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Soldier]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Strength d6+, Vigor d6+

Professional soldiers get used to carrying heavy loads and enduring harsh conditions. After a few days getting used to their gear (GM’s call), they treat their Strength as one die type higher when determining @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Encumbrance} and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Minimum Strength} to use armor, weapons, and equipment without a penalty. (This stacks with the Brawny Edge.)

They also get a free reroll on Vigor rolls made to survive environmental hazards (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{Hazards}).

This Edge has no effect on Armor Interference or Armor Restriction.

Thief

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Thief]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Agility d8+, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Stealth]{Stealth} d6+, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Thievery]{Thievery} d6+

Thieves specialize in deceit, treachery, and acrobatics. They can be invaluable where traps must be detected, walls must be climbed, and locks must be picked.

Thieves know how to use the slimmest protrusions on walls and window ledges to climb the tallest of buildings, scampering through streets and back alleys like cats. They add +1 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} rolls made to climb in urban areas.

Thieves also know how to use the dark areas between the streetlights of cities to conceal their movements, and add +1 to Stealth rolls when in an urban environment.

Finally, these rogues are— not surprisingly—
adept at Thievery itself, adding +1 to those rolls in all circumstances.

Troubadour

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Troubadour]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Common Knowledge]{Common Knowledge} d6+, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Performance]{Performance} d8+

Troubadours travel the world, learning culture, etiquette, history, and above all, legends. They add +2 to Common Knowledge rolls and may use Performance in place of Battle for Leadership Edges or Edges that require Battle.

Woodsman

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Woodsman]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Spirit d6+, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Survival]{Survival} d8+

Woodsmen are rangers, scouts, and hunters who are more at home in the wilderness than urban areas. They are skilled trackers and scouts, and know how to live off the land for months at a time.

Woodsmen add +2 to Survival and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Stealth]{Stealth} rolls made in the wild (not towns, ruins, or underground).

Social Edges

Getting people to do what you want is a critical skill, whether by coercion or charm.

Bolster

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Bolster]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Spirit d8+

Belittling or humiliating an enemy can boost your ally’s spirits. When this character successfully Tests a foe, he may also remove the Distracted or Vulnerable state (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{here}) from one of his allies.

Common Bond

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Common Bond]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Wild Card, Novice, Spirit d8+

Selfless heroes and determined leaders know their greatest strength often comes from their companions, and are willing to give some of their own fortune, fate, or luck to support them.

A character with this Edge may freely give her Bennies to any other character she can communicate with. The player should explain what form this takes, from a quick shout of encouragement to a welcome pat on the back.

Connections

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Connections]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice

Your heroine is connected to people or organizations who can help her when the chips are down. It might be the city guard, a guild, a wealthy noblewoman, or even other adventurers.

Connections may be taken more than once, selecting a new faction or contact each time. Once per session, and assuming she can get in touch with them, the heroine can call on her friends for a favor.

The favor depends on the nature of the contact (GM’s call), but might include a loan, gear, a few allied fighters, transportation, information, or even a professional with critical skills the party doesn’t have, like a tracker or scholar.

Humiliate

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Humiliate]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunt} d8+

Those with a cruel wit can destroy a rival’s ego in a single remark or well-timed gesture. Your hero gets a free reroll on Taunt Tests.

Menacing

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Menacing]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, any one of Bloodthirsty, Mean, Ruthless, or Ugly

Being a brutish lout isn’t always a drawback if you know how to use it. Menacing allows a character to put her bad looks or worse attitude to good use. The goon adds +2 to her @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation} rolls.

Provoke

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Provoke]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunt} d6+

Clever characters can manipulate their foes, drawing enemy focus on themselves to protect their allies. Once per turn, when your hero uses Taunt for a Test and gets a raise (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Test}), she may Provoke the foe.

In addition to all the usual effects of the success and raise, the enemy suffers a −2 penalty to affect any other target besides the one who provoked her. This stacks with Distracted but not further instances of Provoke.

Provoke lasts until a Joker is drawn, someone else Provokes the target, or the encounter ends. Provoke may be combined with Rabble Rouser (see below).

Rabble-Rouser

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Rabble-Rouser]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Spirit d8+

This instigator knows how to rile up several enemies at once. As a limited action, a character with this Edge can make a social Test with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunt} against all enemies in a Medium Blast Template. The targets must be able to see and hear the hero clearly. Each defender resists and is affected by the Test separately.

Reliable

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Reliable]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Spirit d8+

People know they can depend on your hero when they need assistance. He gets a free reroll on any Support roll.

Retort

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Retort]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunt} d6+

This verbal duelist can turn the slings and arrows of social combat right back at the unwitting fools who hurled them.

If a character with Retort gets a raise when resisting an @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation} or Taunt Test, the foe is Distracted.

Streetwise

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Streetwise]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Smarts d6+

Streetwise characters know how to find the local black market, fence stolen goods, avoid the local law (or criminal element!), lay low when the heat’s on, obtain illegal weapons, find out which “boss” is hiring muscle, or similar shady activities.

Streetwise characters add +2 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion} rolls made to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04networking0000]{Network} with shady or criminal elements. They also add +2 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Common Knowledge]{Common Knowledge} rolls pertaining to the types of disreputable activities listed above.

Strong Willed

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Strong Willed]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Spirit d8+

Self-confidence is powerful armor against those who attempt to attack this individual’s will. He adds +2 to his total when resisting Tests with Smarts or Spirit.

Iron Will

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Iron Will]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Brave, Strong Willed

The hero now adds his Strong Willed bonus to resist powers and negate their effects. Iron Will doesn’t stack with Brave, nor does it apply to subsequent rolls resulting from powers such as being Shaken by a damaging power, fear, or the like.

Work the Room

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Work the Room]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Spirit d8+

Your hero’s words don’t just inspire those they’re directed at— they often inspire others as well. Once per turn, you can use Work the Room to roll an additional skill die when Supporting with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Performance]{Performance}. The additional die Supports any other ally who can see or hear your hero, and applies to their next action, whatever it may be.

Work the Crowd

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Work the Crowd]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Seasoned, Work the Room

As Work the Room but the hero now can Support another on up to two of her Support actions.

Weird Edges

Weird Edges are slightly supernatural in origin. These are usually appropriate in a Pathfinder for Savage Worlds game, but check with your GM before taking them.

Beast Bond

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Beast Bond]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice

Some individuals have an extraordinary bond with their animal companions. These characters may spend their own Bennies for any animals under their control, including mounts, pets, familiars, and so on.

Beast Master

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Beast Master]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Spirit d8+

Animals take to your hero quickly and easily. They won’t attack him unless he attacks them first or they’re enraged for some reason.

The Beast Master’s “animal magnetism” is so great he’s attracted a loyal animal of some sort as well. This is typically an animal of Size 0 or smaller, subject to the GM’s approval.

The beast is an Extra and doesn’t Advance in Rank or abilities. If a pet is dismissed or killed, the hero gains a replacement in 1d4 days.

More Powerful Companions: Beast Master may be taken more than once. Choose one of the effects below each time it’s chosen:

  • Gain an additional pet.
  • Increase one of the pet’s Traits one die type (only one Trait per pet).
  • Increase the maximum Size pet you may have by +1, to a maximum of 3.
  • Make one pet a Wild Card. (The hero must be of Heroic Rank).

Champion

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Champion]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Spirit d8+, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} d6+

Champions are holy (or unholy) men and women chosen to fight for a particular deity or religion. Most are pious souls ready and willing to lay down their lives for a greater cause, but some may have been born into the role and follow their path with some reluctance.

Champions fight the forces of darkness (or good), adding +2 damage when attacking supernaturally evil (or good if they’re evil) creatures. The bonus applies to area effect damage, ranged attacks, powers, etc.

The GM must decide which foes this bonus applies to, but generally it’s any evil (or good!) creature born of magic or with any supernatural abilities.

Danger Sense

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Danger Sense]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice

Your hero can sense when something bad is about to happen. When rolling for @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Surprise}, he adds +2 to his @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice} roll to act in the first round. With a raise, he starts the encounter on @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Hold}.

In other situations not covered by the Surprise rules (a sniper shot, pit trap, poisoned drink, etc.), Danger Sense gives him a Notice roll at −2 (or +2 if a Notice roll is usually allowed) to detect the hazard and take appropriate action. If this was an attack and the hero makes his Notice roll, the foe doesn’t get @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{The Drop} against him.

Healer

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Healer]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Spirit d8+

A hero with this Edge gets a free reroll on all @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Healing]{Healing} rolls, whether natural or magical in nature.

Scavenger

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Scavenger]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Novice, Luck

Once per encounter the hero may find, “suddenly remember,” or dig up some much-needed piece of equipment, a quiver half-full of arrows, or some other useful device.

The Game Master decides what constitutes an encounter, and has the final word on what can and can’t be found.

Legendary Edges

Followers

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Followers]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Wild Card, Legendary

Each time this Edge is chosen, five followers come to fight by the hero’s side. If any are lost, others eventually take their place (how long is up to the GM and the circumstances).

Followers must be cared for and generally want a share of whatever loot, treasure, or other rewards the hero acquires. Otherwise, they are completely dedicated to their task. They won’t throw their lives away but are willing to risk them repeatedly in his service.

Use the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Soldier]{Soldier} profile for the followers. A hero may outfit her allies as she sees fit. Use the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04allies00000000]{Allies} rules to give them distinctive personalities if desired.

Professional

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Professional]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Legendary, maximum die type possible in affected Trait

The character is an expert at a particular skill or attribute (his choice). This increases the Trait and its limit one step (a d12+1 becomes a d12+2, for example). This Edge may be selected once per Trait.

Expert

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Expert]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Legendary, Professional in affected Trait

As the Professional Edge, increasing the Trait and its limit one additional step.

Master

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Master]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Wild Card, Legendary, Expert in affected Trait

The character’s Wild Die increases to a d10 when rolling the selected Expert Trait.

Sidekick

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Sidekick]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Wild Card, Legendary

A character who triumphs over evil time and time again becomes an inspiration to others. Eventually, one of these young crusaders may attempt to join the hero’s epic quests.

The hero gains a Novice Rank sidekick. The sidekick is a Wild Card, starts each session with two Bennies, may Advance, and has abilities that complement his mentor. The player character controls his sidekick just like any other ally, though he may occasionally cause trouble by getting captured, running into danger when he’s not supposed to, and so on. The player should be prepared for this Edge to occasionally become a Hindrance!

If the sidekick dies, he isn’t replaced unless the hero chooses this Edge again. Fortunately, heroes may always spend Bennies for their sidekicks as if they had the Common Bond Edge. Sidekicks must actually take that Edge to do the same for their mentors.

Tough As Nails

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Tough As Nails]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Legendary, Vigor d8+

Your character keeps going when others fall. She can take four Wounds before she’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated} (her maximum Wound penalty is still −3).

Tougher Than Nails

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Tougher Than Nails]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Legendary, Tough as Nails, Vigor d12+

The hero can take up to five Wounds before she’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}! Her maximum Wound penalty is still −3.

Weapon Master

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Weapon Master]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Legendary, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} d12+

The warrior increases his Parry by +1 and the bonus damage die for Fighting rolls is a d8 instead of a d6 (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Bonus Damage}). He must be armed to gain these benefits, but this includes claws or other abilities that count as weapons.

Master of Arms

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Master of Arms]{Link to Journal Entry}

Requirements: Legendary, Weapon Master

Increase the hero’s Parry an additional +1 and his @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} bonus damage die is now a d10.

Advancement.name: Advancement
Advancement.text:
Advancement

One of the many great aspects of roleplaying games is advancing your character, watching her grow from a Novice adventurer to a Legendary hero.

Advances are granted by the Game Master at the end of some game "sessions" (about 4–5 hours of play).

An Advance lets a character make one of the adjustments listed below. Remember that no @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Trait} may be raised above its maximum (usually d12 unless modified by an ancestral ability, Edge, etc).

  • Attribute: Increase one attribute one die type. This option may be taken only once per Rank. Legendary characters may raise an attribute no more than every fourth Advance, up to the ancestral or class maximum.
  • Skills: Increase a skill that is equal to or greater than its linked attribute one die type;
    OR increase two skills that are lower than their linked attributes by one die type each (including new skills the character didn’t have before at d4). You cannot increase the same skill twice with the same Advance.
  • Edge: Gain a new Edge. You should have a story-based reason to take a Background or a core @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edgesummarie00]{Class Edge}. You can’t become a barbarian overnight, after all. Gaining these @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edges} should usually take years or some dramatic change in the character’s life, and should only be done with the Game Master’s permission. Core Class Edges and core @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edgesummarie00]{Prestige Edges} are also limited to one per Rank. Legendary characters may choose a core Class Edge (or Prestige Edge) no more than every fourth Advance.
  • Buy Off a Hindrance: Permanently remove a Minor @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrancesum00]{Hindrance}, or reduce a Major Hindrance to a Minor (if possible). The player and GM should work out how and when this happens. Perhaps the shocking death of an ally triggers a change in attitude, the hero puts real effort into improving harmful behavior, or seeks professional help during @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04downtime000000]{Downtime}.

Advancement Pace

How fast characters Advance in Savage Pathfinder depends on the campaign.

  • Official Adventure Paths: These epic tales tell the Game Master when to give the party an Advance. They typically start at Novice Rank and end at Legendary+, spreading improvements along as the story advances to different stages.
  • Short Campaigns: If you’re running a campaign of your own creation and expect it to last 10 sessions or less, we recommend giving characters an Advance after each session.
  • Long Campaigns: Grant an Advance after every two or three sessions for a long campaign, slowing it down to every four or five sessions once the heroes hit Heroic Rank.
  • Milestone Campaigns: Grant an Advance after certain objectives are met in the campaign. You can grant Advances a bit more often in the early stages, slowing things down in the middle and later chapters.

Allies & Advancement

Followers and other allies who stay with the party for extended periods can improve their abilities as well.

If the party advances and the Game Master feels the allies have played a significant role in the story, they Advance as well. This gives player characters a group of loyal retainers and hirelings to interact with and deepens immersion.

You’ll find an Ally Sheet on our website the group can fill in and use to keep up with their retainers' profile, gear, history, and other notes.

Trait Summaries.name: Trait Summaries
Trait Summaries.text:
Trait summaries

Attributes
Agility: Nimbleness, dexterity, and overall physical coordination of muscles and reflexes.
Smarts: Raw intellect, perception, and ability to sort and make use of complex information.
Spirit: Inner strength and willpower.
Strength: Raw muscle power.
Vigor: Endurance, health, and constitution.
Skills
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Academics]{Academics} (Smarts): Knowledge or ability to research written or recorded information.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (Agility): Overall athletic coordination and ability. Climbing, jumping, balancing, wrestling, skiing, swimming, throwing, or catching.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Battle]{Battle} (Smarts): Strategy, tactics, and understanding military operations. A key skill in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04massbattles000]{Mass Battles}.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Boating]{Boating} (Agility): Ability to sail or pilot a boat, ship, or other watercraft.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Common Knowledge]{Common Knowledge} (Smarts): General knowledge of a character’s world.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Driving]{Driving} (Agility): The ability to control, steer, and operate ground vehicles.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Faith]{Faith} (Spirit): The arcane skill for @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Arcane Background (Miracles)]{Arcane Background (Miracles)}.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} (Agility): Skill and utter ferocity in armed and unarmed combat.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Gambling]{Gambling} (Smarts): Skill and familiarity with games of chance.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Healing]{Healing} (Smarts): The ability to treat and heal Wounds and diseases, and decipher forensic evidence.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation} (Spirit): A character’s ability to threaten others into doing what she wants.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice} (Smarts): General awareness and perception.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Occult]{Occult} (Smarts): Knowledge of supernatural events, creatures, history, items, and ways.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Performance]{Performance} (Spirit): Singing, dancing, acting, or other forms of public expression.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion} (Spirit): The ability to convince others to do what you want.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Piloting]{Piloting} (Agility): Skill with maneuvering vehicles that operate in three dimensions, such as airships.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Repair]{Repair} (Smarts): The ability to fix mechanical and electrical gadgets.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Riding]{Riding} (Agility): A character’s skill in mounting, controlling, and riding a tamed beast.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Science]{Science} (Smarts): Knowledge of scientific fields such as biology, chemistry, geology, engineering, etc.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} (Agility): Precision with any type of ranged weapon.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Spellcasting]{Spellcasting} (Smarts): The arcane skill for @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Arcane Background (Magic)]{Arcane Background (Magic)}.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Stealth]{Stealth} (Agility): The ability to sneak and hide.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Survival]{Survival} (Smarts): How to find food, water, or shelter, and tracking.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunt} (Smarts): Insulting or belittling another. Almost always done as a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Test}.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Thievery]{Thievery} (Agility): Sleight of hand, pickpocketing, lockpicking, and other typically shady feats.

Hindrance Summaries.name: Hindrance Summaries
Hindrance Summaries.text:
Hindrance summaries

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.All Thumbs]{All Thumbs} (Minor): –2 to use mechanical or electrical devices.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Anemic]{Anemic} (Minor): –2 Vigor when resisting @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Fatigue}.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Arrogant]{Arrogant} (Major): Likes to dominate his opponent, challenge the most powerful foe in combat.

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Bad Eyes]{Bad Eyes} (Minor/Major): –1 to all @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Trait} rolls dependent on vision, or –2 as a Major@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrances0000]{Hindrance}. Eyewear negates penalty but have a 50% chance of breaking when the hero suffers trauma.

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Bad Luck]{Bad Luck} (Major): The characters starts with one less @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Benny} per session.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Big Mouth]{Big Mouth} (Minor): Unable to keep secrets and constantly gives away private information.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Blind]{Blind} (Major): –6 to all tasks that require vision (but choice of a free @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edge} to offset).
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Bloodthirsty]{Bloodthirsty} (Major): Never takes prisoners.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Can't Swim]{Can't Swim} (Minor): –2 to swimming (@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics}) rolls; Each inch moved in water costs 3” of Pace.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Cautious]{Cautious} (Minor): The character plans extensively and/or is overly careful.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Clueless]{Clueless} (Major): –1 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Common Knowledge]{Common Knowledge} and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice} rolls.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Clumsy]{Clumsy} (Major): –2 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Stealth]{Stealth} rolls.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Code of Honor]{Code of Honor} (Major): The character keeps his word and acts like a gentleman.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Curious]{Curious} (Major): The character wants to know about everything.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Death Wish]{Death Wish} (Minor): The hero wants to die after or while completing some epic task.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Delusional]{Delusional} (Minor/Major): The individual believes something strange that causes him occasional or frequent trouble.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Driven]{Driven} (Minor/Major): The hero’s actions are driven by some important goal or belief.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Elderly]{Elderly} (Major): –1 to Pace, running, Agility, Strength, and Vigor. Hero gets 5 extra skill points.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Enemy]{Enemy} (Minor/Major): The character has a recurring nemesis.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Greedy]{Greedy} (Minor/Major): The individual is obsessed with wealth and material possessions.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Habit]{Habit} (Minor/Major): Addicted to something, suffers @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Fatigue} if deprived.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Hard of Hearing]{Hard of Hearing} (Minor/Major): –4 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice} sounds; automatic failure if completely deaf.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Heroic]{Heroic} (Major): The character always helps those in need.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Hesitant]{Hesitant} (Minor): Draw two @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Action Cards} and take the lowest (except Jokers, which may be kept).
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Illiterate]{Illiterate} (Minor): The character cannot read or write.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Impulsive]{Impulsive} (Major): The hero leaps before he looks.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Jealous]{Jealous} (Minor/Major): The individual covets what others have.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Loyal]{Loyal} (Minor): The hero is loyal to his friends and allies.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Mean]{Mean} (Minor): –1 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion} rolls.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Mild Mannered]{Mild Mannered} (Minor): –2 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation} rolls.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Mute]{Mute} (Major): The hero cannot speak.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Obese]{Obese} (Minor): @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Size} +1, Pace –1 and running die of d4. Treat Str as one die type lower for Min Str.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Obligation]{Obligation} (Minor/Major): The character has a weekly obligation of 20 (Minor) to 40 (Major) hours.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.One Arm]{One Arm} (Major): –4 to tasks (such as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics}) that require two hands.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.One Eye]{One Eye} (Major): –2 to actions at 5″ (10 yards) or more distance.

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Outsider]{Outsider} (Minor/Major): The character doesn’t fit in to the local environment and subtracts 2 from @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion} rolls. As a Major Hindrance she has no legal rights or other serious consequences.

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Overconfident]{Overconfident} (Major): The hero believes she can do anything.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Pacifist]{Pacifist} (Minor/Major): Fights only in self-defense as a Minor Hindrance, won’t fight at all as Major.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Phobia]{Phobia} (Minor/Major): The character is afraid of something, and subtracts –1/–2 from all @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Trait rolls} in its presence.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Poverty]{Poverty} (Minor): Half starting funds and the character is always broke.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Quirk]{Quirk} (Minor): The individual has some minor but persistent foible that often annoys others.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Ruthless]{Ruthless} (Minor/Major): The character does what it takes to get her way.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Secret]{Secret} (Minor/Major): The hero has a dark secret of some kind.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Shamed]{Shamed} (Minor/Major): The individual is haunted by some tragic event from her past.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Slow]{Slow} (Minor/Major):@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Pace} –1, reduce running die one step. As Major, Pace –2, –2 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} and rolls to resist Athletics. Neither may take the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Fleet-Footed]{Fleet-Footed} Edge.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Small]{Small} (Minor): @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Size} and Toughness are reduced by 1. Size cannot be reduced below –1.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Stubborn]{Stubborn} (Minor): The character wants his way and rarely admits his mistakes.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Suspicious]{Suspicious} (Minor/Major): The individual is paranoid. As a Major@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrances0000]{Hindrance}, allies subtract 2 when rolling to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Support} him.

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Thin Skinned]{Thin Skinned} (Minor/Major): The character is particularly susceptible to personal attacks. As a Minor Hindrance, he subtracts two when resisting @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunt} attacks. As a Major, he subtracts four.

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Timid]{Timid} (Major): –2 to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04fear0000000000]{Fear} checks and resisting @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation}.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Tongue-Tied]{Tongue-Tied} (Major): The character often misspeaks or can’t get her words out. –1 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion}, and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunt} rolls.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Ugly]{Ugly} (Minor/Major): The character is physically unattractive and subtracts 1 or 2 from @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion} rolls.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Vengeful]{Vengeful} (Minor/Major): The adventurer seeks payback for slights against her. As a Major Hindrance, she’ll cause physical harm to get it.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Vow]{Vow} (Minor/Major): The individual has pledged himself to some cause.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Wanted]{Wanted} (Minor/Major): The character is wanted by the authorities.
@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Young]{Young} (Minor/Major): Minor has 4 attribute points and 10 skill points, extra Benny per session. Major has 3 attribute points, 10 skill points, and two extra @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Bennies} per session.
