This is an action, which must be the second part of a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Multi-Action} if the attack is successful. The foe resists the casting with an opposed Spirit roll against the arcane skill total and is sent up to 12″ away with success and 24″ with a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise}. Foes may not be teleported into solid objects.

Time Stop

See power @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Time Stop]{here}.

Rank: Heroic

Power Points: 8

Range: Self

Duration: Instant

School: Transmutation

Trappings: A glowing hourglass, floating ice particles, blurring.

Time is a constant for most, but not this spellcaster. The spell slows time for all but the caster, granting her a new turn immediately after she finishes this one. With a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise}, she gets up to four actions on the turn instead of three and can ignore up to 2 points of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Multi-Action} penalties. Time stop can only be cast once per round.

Wall Walker

See power @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Wall Walker]{here}.

Rank: Novice

Power Points: 2

Range: Smarts

Duration: 5

School: Transmutation

Trappings: Spider-like visage, prickly hairs on hands and feet.

Wall walker allows the recipient to walk on vertical or horizontal surfaces. With success, she moves at half her normal Pace. With a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise}, she may move at full Pace and even run.

If forced to make an @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll to climb or hang on to a surface, she adds +4 to the total.

Modifiers

See generic modifiers @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{here}

  • Additional Recipients (+1): The caster may affect others at the cost of 1 @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Point} each.

Warrior's Gift

See power @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Warrior's Gift]{here}.

Rank: Seasoned

Power Points: 4

Range: Smarts

Duration: 5

School: Conjuration

Trappings: Gestures, prayer, whispered words, concentration.

With a successful arcane skill roll, the recipient gains the benefits of a single Combat Edge chosen by the caster. The caster (not the recipient) must have the same Rank or higher as the Edge’s Requirements. With a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise}, the recipient gains the Improved version of the Edge (if there is one, and even if he doesn’t meet the Rank Requirement).

Modifiers

See generic modifiers @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{here}

  • Additional Recipients (+1): The power may affect more than one target for 1 additional @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Point} each.
  • Power (+4): The recipient gains two Combat Edges at once.

Wish

See power @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Wish]{here}.

Rank: Legendary

Power Points: 20

Range: Smarts

Duration: Instant

School: Universal

Trappings: A jinn from a bottle, clicked heels, an incantation, a monkey’s paw.

Wish allows a character to bend reality to his will. It is taxing to alter reality, however, so the caster must permanently sacrifice 3 of his own Power Points (after the spell is cast). A @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise} on the arcane skill roll eliminates this cost.

A caster may wish for any one of the following effects per casting, chosen before the roll is made:

  • Activate a Power: Wish casts any other available power, including modifiers, available in the campaign with a raise. If the spell is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{opposed}, the target rolls with a −2 penalty on top of any other modifiers. If the Power Points required to activate the power and modifiers are greater than the cost of wish, the caster must pay the difference.
  • Intercession: The caster wishes for some form of aid, which typically appears after a short period of time. A party trapped in a collapsed dungeon might wish for escape only to be rescued by a party of dwarven miners. A spellcaster could wish to know the true name of a powerful demon and be contacted the next day by a traitorous subordinate of the creature.
  • Gain an Edge: The caster can gain (or grant another) a permanent @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edge}. The recipient must meet the Edge’s Requirements and can never gain more than one Edge from a wish.
  • Wealth: The spellcaster wishes for up to 10,000 gp worth of goods, including anything from transportation to supplies to magic items. Such goods generally sell for a quarter of their value. The wealth doesn’t appear from nothing but rather comes to the caster via events contrived by the GM.
  • Travel Back Through Time: The caster travels back in time for a short period: one minute outside of combat or back to the start of the current round in combat. Everything that happened in that period is reversed except for the caster's @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Points}, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Bennies}, and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds}.
    The GM should do her best to remember all other actors' state of things from the start of the round, but warping time is imperfect so don't worry about getting everything exactly right.
    Once reversed, only the caster remembers the alternate sequence of events, and that period of time cannot be altered again.
  • See the Future: The caster peers into the near or far future. A look into the near future grants her three @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Conviction} tokens that must be used by the caster or anyone she's currently in contact with (mental, verbal, in sight, etc.) within the next five rounds. At the end of the fifth round, any remaining tokens are discarded. A look into the far future allows the caster to ask the Game Master one question about the future and receive as accurate an answer as possible. Actions by the spellcaster can change the future, however, so this may only be the most likely path or a warning of future dangers.
  • Raise a Trait: Wish can permanently increase a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Trait} one die type. This increases the Trait’s limit by one die type as well. A recipient may never have more than one Trait raised by a wish.
  • Restore Fate: The hero and all @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Cards} in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Range} may refill their @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Bennies} to their usual starting maximum.
  • Special: The character may change relatively minor aspects of herself, others, or the world around her (if the subject of the wish doesn’t want to be affected, it’s resisted with a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Spirit} roll at −2). This shouldn’t cause any far-reaching changes to the world or history, shouldn’t be covered by one of the abilities above, and is completely at the whim of the Game Master. A caster can change her gender, ancestry, languages, etc., but these changes do not alter time and are thus not retroactive.
    Wish can improve someone’s mood (and their attitude on the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-tables.Reaction]{Reaction Table}, if appropriate), but it can’t permanently affect free will. It can’t force a change of heart or make someone harm themselves.

Zombie Creatures

Animals and other creatures can also be raised with this foul ability! The cost is 2 for a creature of Size -1 or -1, 3 for Size 0, and 1 for a Small Swarm, 2 for a Medium Swarm, or 3 for a Large.

Larger creatures cost 3 + Size in Power Points. For example, and undead grizzly (Size 2) costs 5 Power Points to raise.

Magical or supernatural @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08specialabili00]{Special Abilities} aren't conferred to the undead form, but those inherent to the creature are, such as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Improved Frenzy]{Improved Frenzy}, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Reach}, a swarm's attack, etc.

Additional zombie creatures cost half their base cost if raised at once, instead of the +1 listed for Additional Zombies (round up, minimum of 1).

Zombie

See power @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Zombie]{here}.

Rank: Veteran

Power Points: 3 (See sidebar for large creatures)

Range: Smarts

Duration: One hour

School: Necromancy

Trappings: Carving symbols on corpses, throwing bones, graveyards.

Zombie grants animation and basic intelligence to the remains of a once-living being. The summoned horror is obedient but literal-minded in its duties. It isn’t telepathic, and must be controlled by voice.

The being has the physical skills it had in life, but its Smarts, Spirit, and related skills are reset to d4. A @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise} on the casting roll increases any one of their Traits one die type (caster’s choice).

See @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Zombie, Human]{here} for the standard profile of a human zombie. Corpses aren’t summoned by this ability, so there must actually be a supply of bodies in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Range} (GM’s call).

An undead @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated} by damage can’t be raised with this power again.

Modifiers

See generic modifiers @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{here}

  • Additional Zombies (+1): A larger horde can be raised in a single casting by paying an additional 1 @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Point} for each extra zombie raised.
  • Armed (+1 per Zombie): The dead rise with a weapon common to their background or environment. Choose one:
    • Hand Weapon: Str+d6.
    • Ranged Weapon: Range 12/24/48, Damage 2d6.
  • Armor (+1 per Zombie): The horrors crawl from their grave wearing 2 points of Armor. This might be old chain mail, rusting plate, rotting leather, etc.
  • Mind Rider (+1/+3): The caster can communicate and sense through one of the undead he’s conjured. If it’s destroyed, he may jump to any of the others currently under his control. For 3 points, Mind Rider affects all the zombies created in this summoning.
  • Permanent (0): The zombie is given unlife until Incapacitated by @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds}. The Power Points used to raise it are “invested” and unavailable until it’s destroyed. The necromancer may terminate his creations’ unlife at any time, regardless of sight, distance, or other factors. His @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Points} then begin recharging normally.
    Permanent zombies remain animated even if their creator is slain!
  • SKELETAL (+1 per Zombie): The corpse sloughs off the anchor of dead flesh and rises as a skeleton. This increases its @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Agility}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting}, and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} dice by one die type each.

Trappings.name: Trappings
Trappings.text:
Trappings

Trappings allow the core powers presented in this chapter to have many different appearances. They don't usually have a game effect of their own, but are important for atmosphere and theme.

One character might fire magical missiles of glowing white energy while another hurls deadly icicles. Both use the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Bolt]{bolt} power and share the same mechanics, but they look and "feel" different.

Trappings do matter when an obstacle or opponent has a particular strength or weakness. If an ice troll suffers +4 damage from fire- or heat-based attacks, for example, a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Blast]{blast} a player describes as a fireball counts as a fire attack and does +4 damage.

Once described, a power’s Trappings don’t change unless the caster uses an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01advancement000]{Advance}.

A character can alter the power’s effects or Trappings as she wishes using @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{Power Modifiers}.

Synergy

Sometimes logic dictates a power’s Trapping should have some additional effect. Zapping someone with a lightning bolt while they’re standing in water should cause additional damage, for example.

When this occurs, the GM can decide there’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{synergy} that either increases or decreases the effect or damage (GM’s call) by +2 or −2.

Oppositional forces, such as fire and ice or light and darkness, don’t have synergy against one another (though such effects are sometimes accounted for in some creatures’ @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08specialabili00]{Special Abilities)}. If a fire blast hits ice armor@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Protection]{(protection)}, for example, there’s no additional effect because they cancel each other out.

Adding & Changing Trappings

A character can learn two new powers when he takes the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.New Powers]{New Powers} Edge. He may instead add Trappings to his powers in place of one or two of the new powers. A hero who takes the New Powers Edge, for example, could choose one new power and add an ice Trapping to her @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Bolt]{bolt}. The GM may also allow a player to change the Trapping of existing power when she gains an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01advancement000]{Advance}. This should reflect a major change in the character in some way as determined by the player and GM.

Limitations

Sometimes a power’s Trapping imposes a limitation on the power. This gives the power focus at the expense of versatility. The @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Limitation} is permanent and always in effect unless changed with an Advance as noted below.

Each limitation placed upon the power reduces its total @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Points} cost by one (to a minimum of 1). If this would normally reduce the cost to 0, you gain a +1 bonus (+2 maximum) to the arcane skill total instead.

  • Range: The power’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Range} is reduced to Touch (if its usual Range is greater).
  • Personal: The power’s Range becomes Self (if its usual Range is Touch or it has the range Limitation, above). This includes an item if the power is normally cast on an object (such as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Smite]{smite}).
  • Aspect: The character can only access one aspect of a power (that has more than one choice), such as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Sloth/Speed]{sloth/speed} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Boost/Lower Trait]{boost/lower} Trait.

Activation.name: Activation
Activation.text:
Activation

A character activates a power by picking a target within @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Range} and making an arcane skill roll. Failure means the power doesn’t activate. The caster spends one @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Point} regardless of any Edges such as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Channeling]{Channeling}, unless the ability specifically says it reduces the minimum cost to 0.

Success means the power activates and consumes all the Power Points allocated to it, even if it misses the target (such as with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Bolt]{bolt}), or the defender resists. A @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise} has additional effects noted in the particular power description.

Backlash: A @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Critical Failure} when activating a power is called @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05activation0000]{Backlash}. It causes a level of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Fatigue} and all currently active powers instantly terminate.

Casting Requirements

A character must be able to see his target and cannot be @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Bound} or silenced.

Maintaining Powers

When a power ends, the caster can spend one @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Point} to extend it by its base @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{Duration}. If a power’s Duration is five rounds, for example, it can be maintained for another five rounds for 1 Power Point.

Maintenance is per target but ignores other @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{Power Modifiers}, so renewing@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Boost/Lower Trait]{boost Trait} on three allies costs 3 Power Points and extends the effect of each another five rounds.

Unless a power says otherwise, the caster can terminate it as a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{free action}.

Stacking Powers

Powers don't stack beyond their maximum benefit or drawback. This includes effects from magic items that specifically use those powers. A ring that simply says it increases Strength a die type does so even if the wearer's Strength is currently increased by boost Trait(Strength), for example. If the same ring said it boosts Strength a die type, however, it would only stack with the actual spell or other items up to the power's maximum (two die types).

Powers that target different Traits or abilities, such as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Boost/Lower Trait]{boost/lower Trait}, are considered separate powers in this context. Strength may only be increased up to two die types by boost Trait, for example, but Strength and Fighting could both be boosted up to two die types as each one is a separate Trait. Similarly, a sorcerer could cast @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Protection]{protection} (melee) on an ally who's already benefiting from a ring of @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-gear.Ring of Protection, Minor]{protection} (ranged).

Recharging

A character recovers 5 @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Points} per hour spent resting.

What constitutes rest is up to the GM, but generally, it means sitting, eating, tending wounds, sleeping, and avoiding any strenuous activity. Walking or riding a horse isn’t usually restful, but riding in a cushioned carriage might be.

A few interruptions don’t stop a character from resting— standing watch, planning, sharpening weapons, and so on (GM’s call).

An arcane hero can also spend a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Benny} to regain five Power Points. This is a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{free action}.

Powers As Multi-Actions

Each power activated is its own action, and the same or dif­ferent powers may be cast multiple times as a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Multi-Action}. A wizard might start combat by invoking @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Protection]{protection} and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Deflection]{deflection}, for example, or a priest might attempt to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Banish]{banish} a spirit while invoking @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Smite]{smite} on his mace.

Shorting

A character may cast a power with fewer @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Points} than required (whether she has them or not) by increasing the difficulty of her arcane skill roll (If there is no skill roll, as with Mystic Powers, the character cannot short the power).

For every Power Point a character shorts, she suffers a −1 penalty to the roll. Casting a 3-point @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Healing]{healing} with 0 Power Points, for example, inflicts a −3 penalty.

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05activation0000]{Shorting} is risky. If a character fails a shorted arcane skill roll, it’s consid­ered a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Critical Failure!}

Power Modifiers.name: Power Modifiers
Power Modifiers.text:
Power Modifiers

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{Power Modifiers} allow characters to customize their abilities, adding a special effect that better reflects their power’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping}.

Power Modifiers are selected when a power is activated and may be freely changed each time. An icy @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Bolt]{bolt} might cause @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Armor Piercing} damage in one attack and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Lingering Damage} in the next.

The common modifiers listed on this page can be used with any power a character is using (unless otherwise prevented from modifying the power). Some powers also list additional specific Power Modifiers that can be used with that power.

Casters must declare which modifiers they’re using before rolling their arcane skill. The number in parentheses is the price in additional @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Points} it costs to add the effect. A Power Modifier may only be applied once per casting.

Duration: Power Modifiers last for the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{Duration} of the spell, or until the end of the target’s next turn in the case of Instant powers.

Epic Powers: Some Power Modifiers are marked with a gold star. These are Epic Powers requiring the Arcane or Divine Mastery Edges.

Adaptable caster (+1)

The caster can spend one extra @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Point} when activating a power to alter its @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping}. This can have important consequences if a foe has a particular resistance to the spell’s usual Trapping or weakness to the new one!

Armor Piercing (+1 to +3)

The attack is focused to defeat armor or seeks out a foe’s exposed areas. Each Power Point spent grants the power @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{AP} 2 to a max­imum of AP 6.

Fatigue (+2)

Powers that drain or tax an opponent can cause @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Fatigue}. The modifier may be attached to any power that can cause damage or is resisted by the target. If she’s affected by the power in any way, she also suffers Fatigue. This cannot cause @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitation}, however.

Glow/Shroud (+1)

Glow creates soft light (caster’s choice of color) in a Small Blast Template centered on the target. It subtracts 2 from her @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Stealth]{Stealth} totals and negates 1 point of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination} penalties for those attacking the glowing character.

Shroud dims and slightly obscures the target so that attacks against her suffer a −1 penalty and she adds +1 to her Stealth rolls.

Heavy Weapon (+2)

The caster creates a focused blast. The attack counts as a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Heavy Weapon}.

Hinder/Hurry (+1)

The target is slowed in some way, perhaps due to intense cold, a slippery surface, or even binding matter or energy. His base Pace is reduced by 2.

A caster can @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{Hurry} the recipient instead, granting increased energy, sure footing, or more powerful muscles. His Pace is increased by 2.

Effects of either modifier aren’t cumulative.

Lingering Damage (+2)

The target is hit by fire, cold, acid, gnawing insects, or some other @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping} that continues to cause damage after the initial attack. On the victim’s next turn, he suffers the power’s base damage minus one die type (for one additional turn only). If hit with a 2d6 @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Bolt]{bolt}, for example, the victim takes 2d4 damage at the start of his next turn. If the base damage is already a d4 die type, it is d4–2 instead.

Range (+1/+2)

Double the power’s listed @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Range} for 1 @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Point}, or triple it for +2. This modifier may not be used on powers with a Range of Touch or the Cone or Stream Template.

Selective (+1)

With intense focus, the caster can choose not to affect any or all individual targets within a power’s area of effect (picking all enemies instead of allies in a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Blast]{blast}, for example).

Cantrips.name: Cantrips
Cantrips.text:
Cantrips

A mage sets a broom to sweeping his floor. A priest lights a candle with the grace of her god. A bard tells an animated story in the night air, illuminated with the dancing cinders of a campfire. Such minor orisons (prayers) or lesser magicks are collectively called "cantrips."

In Pathfinder for Savage Worlds, any character with an Arcane Background (see both Arcane Background and Class Edges @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{here}) can cast cantrips.

Activation

A character may cast a cantrip by making an arcane skill roll. This is an action, and the effect must be based on one of the character’s existing powers. A sorcerer could use @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Bolt]{bolt} with a fire @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping} to light a campfire, for example. A druid could use @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Entangle]{entangle} to make vines dance to entertain a group of children. A wizard can use @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Sound/Silence]{sound} to ring a bell calling a servant to his study.

Success means the desired effect occurs. A @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise} has an additional narrative impact of some kind— the candle glows brightly, the vines dance in perfect synchronicity, or the bell rings loud and pure.

Failure causes the spell to fail without effect. A @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Critical Failure} causes the spell to backfire, which requires the caster to lose 1 @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Points} (or suffer @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Fatigue} if the caster has no Power Points). Critical Failure also causes an embarrassment or minor mishap of some sort— an animated broom carelessly knocks a jar of ink onto the floor, a conjured flame lights a book on fire, or the power makes an embarrassing sound or smell.

A successfully cast cantrip’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{Duration} is the same as the power it’s based on and may be maintained by spending Power Points as usual.

The GM has the final say on what a cantrip can do, but the effect must not replace a power or cause damage (at least directly). It can be used to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Test} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Support}, or grant a +1 bonus on a subsequent roll in the same encounter. For example, if the bard uses a cantrip to impress the children of Sandpoint, the GM might give him +1 to a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion} roll later on if he talks to their parents or someone else who witnessed the kindness.

Arcane Devices.name: Arcane Devices
Arcane Devices.text:
Arcane Devices

A character with the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Artificer]{Artificer} Edge can focus powers into devices for herself or others. The advantage is that they can be given to and used by allies. The trade-off is that devices take a little preparation to create and can be lost or destroyed.

In Pathfinder for Savage Worlds, arcane devices are usually sacred, enchanted, or otherwise magically powered objects in line with the creator’s Arcane Background. For example, a cleric with Artificer may create a silver talisman with the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Relief]{relief} power, while a druid may make a wooden amulet with the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Beast Friend]{beast friend} power.

Note: Arcane devices are relatively temporary items crafters can create with their powers and the Artificer Edge. More permanent magic items are created differently, with additional requirements for ample undisturbed time and resources. See Magic Items entries for more details.

Creation

Creating a device takes one hour per power that can be activated through it. The player must list which powers are in the device and then allocate @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Points} to it. The device can only use the powers and Power Points allocated to it.

Power Points invested in an arcane device are lost to the inventor until they’re used or recovered with Tinkering.

Power Modifiers: A user may spend a device’s Power Points as desired, including enabling any applicable @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{Power Modifiers}.

Arcane devices may not be @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05activation0000]{Shorted}.

Limitations: Arcane devices may benefit from @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Limitations}.

Activation: The creator uses his arcane skill as usual. Others use whatever skill is associated with the device’s form— bows use @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting}, knives use @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (throwing), and so on. If there is no other obvious skill, such as for a potion or worn item, the character rolls the inventor’s arcane skill as if it were his own (he does not benefit from any of the creator’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edges} or other abilities, however).

Failure to activate the device costs one of the device's @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Point}, and a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Critical Failure} causes the user @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Fatigue}.

Tinkering: A creator can reassign up to five @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Points} per action between an arcane device and her own pool. She must be in physical contact with the item to do so. Characters should lend out their devices very carefully!

Arcane Device Examples

A powerful vizier makes an @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Invisibility]{invisibility} cloak and gives it to one of his spies. He has 20 @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Points} and puts 5 of them into the cloak, reducing his remaining pool to 15.

When the spy wants to turn invisible, she rolls the vizier’s @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Spellcasting]{Spellcasting} skill. This costs 1 less Power Point than usual because of the cloak’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Limitation}— it must be worn to activate so it has a Range of Touch.

The vizier also gives the spy the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Bolt]{bolt} power in the form of a wand and invests it with 10 Power Points. The spy rolls @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} to activate the wand.

The spy suffers @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Fatigue} if she rolls a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Critical Failure} activating either device.

Once the cloak or wand is out of energy, the vizier can recover the Power Points he invested in it normally.

Meanwhile, Ezren the wizard makes an “oil of sharpness” for Valeros the fighter. When rubbed on a sword it activates the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Smite]{smite} power. Ezren invests four Power Points into it. The pair soon find themselves in battle with the undead. Valeros rubs the oil on the blade and rolls Ezren's Spellcasting. The roll fails, which drains the oil of one Power Point. Next turn, Valeros tries again, getting a raise and granting the sword +4 damage. Smite normally costs 2 Power Points but Ezren's Trapping has the Range Limitation so it only costs 1 point for each application. See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trappings}.

Schools of Magic.name: Schools of Magic
Schools of Magic.text:
Schools of Magic

On Golarion, spells are categorized based on the effects generated by the power. These specialized groups are called schools. Any power not tied to a school of magic is considered to be a universal spell, such as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Wish]{wish}. There are eight schools of magic: Abjuration, Conjuration, Divination, Enchantment, Evocation, Illusion, Necromancy, and Transmutation.

A spell is always considered to be from its school, no matter where it comes from. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Boost/Lower Trait]{Boost Trait}, for example, is a Transmutation power, whether its cast from @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Arcane Background (Miracles)]{Arcane Background} (Cleric) or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Arcane Background (Magic)]{Arcane Background}(Sorcerer). The GM may decide, however, that a caster's specific trappings move the power into a different school for that caster (so a GM might rule that, while a typical barrier belongs to the conjuration school, a purely magical barrier might be an evocation spell instead).

Knowing the schools of magic and their effects can be instrumental in identifying magical traps, weapons, items, or auras surrounding an opponent.

Here are the various schools and the powers that belong to each. Note: these lists do not affect which powers an Arcane Background has access to. These lists simply identify which powers are associated to each particular school and the general focus of the school of magic.

  • Abjuration: This is the school of protective magic. It's used to prevent harm and suppress other spells. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Arcane Protection]{Arcane protection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Banish]{banish}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Damage Field]{damage field}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Dispel]{dispel}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Deflection]{deflection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Protection]{protection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Sanctuary]{sanctuary}.
  • Conjuration: This school focuses on altering reality by creating, restoring or moving objects and creatures. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Barrier]{Barrier}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Burrow]{burrow}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Conjure Item]{conjure item}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Healing]{healing}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Planar Binding]{planar binding}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Plane Shift]{plane shift}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Relief]{relief}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Resurrection]{resurrection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Summon Ally]{summon ally}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Teleport]{teleport}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Warrior's Gift]{warrior’s gift}.
  • Divination: This school focuses on predicting the future and learning the secrets held by others. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Detect/Conceal Arcana]{Detect/conceal Arcana}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Divination]{divination}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Locate]{locate}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Mind Link]{mind link}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Mind Reading]{mind reading}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Object Reading]{object reading}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Scrying]{scrying}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Speak Language]{speak language}.
  • Enchantment: This school affects the minds of others, influencing or controlling their behavior. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Beast Friend]{Beast friend}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Confusion]{confusion}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Empathy]{empathy}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Mind Wipe]{mind wipe}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Puppet]{puppet}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Slumber]{slumber}.
  • Evocation: Evocation magic taps into the unseen source of power to produce spectacular effects. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Blast]{Blast}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Bolt]{bolt}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Burst]{burst}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Havoc]{havoc}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Light / Darkness]{light/darkness}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Stun]{stun}.
  • Illusion: This school deceives the senses or minds of others. These spells often cause people to see things that are not there, or not see things that are. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Disguise]{Disguise}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Illusion]{illusion}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Invisibility]{invisibility}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Sound/Silence]{sound/silence}.
  • Necromancy: This school manipulates the power of death, unlife, and the life force. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Blind]{Blind}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Curse]{curse}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Drain Power Points]{drain Power Points}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Fear]{fear}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Boost/Lower Trait]{lower Trait}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Zombie]{zombie}.
  • Transmutation: Transmutation changes the properties of some creature, thing, or condition. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Boost/Lower Trait]{boost Trait}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Darksight]{darksight}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Elemental Manipulation]{elemental manipulation}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Entangle]{entangle}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Environmental Protection]{environmental protection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Farsight]{farsight}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Fly]{fly}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Growth/Shrink]{growth/shrink}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Intangibility]{intangibility}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Shape Change]{shape change}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Sloth/Speed]{sloth/speed}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Smite]{smite}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Telekinesis]{telekinesis}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Time Stop]{time stop}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Wall Walker]{wall walker}.

Rules.name: Rules
Rules.text:
Rules

Savage Pathfinder provides a simple framework for your tales of adventure and glory. In this chapter we show you how to make basic skill and attribute checks--and make your combats Fast, Furious, and Fun!

Wild Cards & Extras

Your hero (a player character), and unique allies, villains, and monsters are collectively called “Wild Cards.” These beings have a better chance at doing things, are a little tougher to put down, and are generally more detailed than common guards, minions, or lackeys-- collectively called “Extras.”

Wild Cards are noted with a design of some sort before their name, like this:

Goblin Warchanter

In Pathfinder for Savage Worlds the Wild Card symbol is a distinctive dragon head.

Player characters are always Wild Cards. The Game Master must decide which of her nonplayer characters and monsters are Wild Cards. The sergeant of the City Watch probably isn’t a Wild Card, but Sergeant Grimlock of the City Watch may be. Skytch the Dragon is also a Wild Card, though his three young wyrms aren’t.

Wild Cards are those who have stepped up to do more than most. They dare, aspire, and risk it all to be a hero--or a villain!

They have two special abilities in the game:

  • Wild Cards can take three @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} before they’re @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}.
  • Wild Cards roll a Wild Die (usually a d6) along with their skill or attribute die when making Trait rolls and take the highest of the two as their total.

Trait Rolls

To make a skill or attribute “check” or “roll,” simply roll the die assigned to it. If the result is a 4 or better (the “Target Number” or TN), the action is successful. For example, if a character’s Strength is a d6, he rolls a six-sided die. On a 4 or better, he’s successful.

Modifiers: Circumstances modify the die roll, such as shooting at something far away or finding a well-hidden clue. Some things, such as @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{ranged attacks}, have standard modifiers. It’s up to the GM to determine any modifiers for more subjective tasks, such as spotting an ambush or eavesdropping on a conversation through a door.

In general, an easy task, such as finding tracks in the mud, is made at +2. A difficult task, such as finding tracks by torchlight, is made at −2. A very difficult task, such as finding tracks in a rainstorm, is made at −4.

Multiple Dice: When a character rolls multiple dice, such as when firing two arrows with the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Rapid Shot]{Rapid Shot} Edge, check each die separately.

The Wild Die

Extras roll a single die when making a Trait roll. @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Cards} roll an extra d6 and take the highest of their Trait die or the “Wild Die.” Both of these dice can Ace (see below).

One Wild Die Per Action: When Wild Cards roll multiple dice for a single action, they roll only one Wild Die. It may replace a Trait die or be ignored--it never adds another action or attack to the roll.

Example: A fighter has the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Frenzy]{Frenzy} Edge. He rolls an extra Fighting die when making a melee attack along with a Wild Die. Only two of his dice can cause hits since the Wild Die can only replace a die, not add another attack.

Aces

All Trait and damage rolls in Savage Pathfinder are open-ended. That means that when you roll the highest number possible on a die (a 6 on a d6, an 8 on a d8, and so on), you get to roll that die again and add it to the total. This is called an “Ace.” Any modifiers to the die roll should be tacked on after adding up an Aced roll.

Example: A rogue attempts to leap a dangerous ice chasm. She’s a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Card} with a d8 in @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics}, so she rolls a d8 and a d6 and takes the highest result. In this case, both dice Ace (8 on the d8 and 6 on the d6). She rolls the d8 again and gets a 4 for a total of 12 on the d8. She rolls the d6 again and gets another 6, followed by a 2—that’s a total of 14 on the Wild Die. The wily rogue leaps the chasm with ease!

Raises

Sometimes it’s important to know just how successful a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Trait roll} was. Every 4 points over the Target Number is called a “raise.” If your hero needs a 4 to shoot an opponent and rolls an 11, he hits with a raise. Figure raises after adjusting for any modifiers.

A raise always provides an additional effect of some sort, such as bonus damage when attacking or a benefit determined by the GM for other rolls.

Opposed Rolls

Sometimes rolls are “opposed” by an opponent. The attacker gets a Trait total, then the defender attempts to beat it.

The exact skills or attributes used in a contest are specified in each circumstance, or the GM can decide what makes the most sense. If two characters try to pull something from each other’s hands, for example, they make opposed Strength rolls. Sneaking up on someone is a Stealth roll opposed by @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice} (which is detailed in the Stealth skill description @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Stealth]{here}).

The acting character in an opposed roll always makes the Trait total first (including spending any @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Bennies}), and must get at least a basic success (TN 4) or he fails. The defender rolls next and must meet or exceed the first character’s result or the attacker wins.

The winner also uses the opponent’s total for purposes of determining raise effects.

Critical Failures

A Critical Failure occurs when a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Card} rolls a 1 on both the skill die and Wild Die of a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Trait roll}. The attempt automatically fails and something bad happens--a weapon is dropped or gets stuck, the attack hits a friend, the vehicle crashes, spells misfire (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05activation0000]{Backlash}), and so on.

Critical Failures cannot be rerolled by any means, even with @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Bennies}.

Extras and Critical Failures: If an Extra rolls a 1 on a Trait check and it’s important to know if it’s a Critical Failure, such as when casting a spell, roll a d6. On a 1, it’s a Critical Failure. Otherwise it’s just a normal failure.

Multiple Dice: Some abilities allow characters to roll multiple Trait dice, such as the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Frenzy]{Frenzy} Edge or firing a weapon with a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Rate of Fire} higher than 1. A Critical Failure with multiple dice occurs when more than half the die results are a natural 1. If the character is a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Card}, the Wild Die must be a 1 as well.

Example: A fighter with the Frenzy Edge rolls two Fighting dice and one Wild Die. If two or more of the dice come up 1s, including the Wild Die, it’s a Critical Failure.

Unskilled Attempts

If a character doesn’t have a skill for an action he’s attempting, he rolls a d4 for his skill die (and a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Die} if a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Card}) and subtracts 2 from the total.

The GM may decide certain tasks cannot be attempted unskilled, such as repairing a steam engine or piloting an airship.

Reroll

Some Edges or abilities allow a character to reroll Traits (as long as they’re not a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Critical Failure}). To do so, roll all the dice again and get a new total. You may keep any set you like unless you roll a Critical Failure. This ends all rerolls immediately and becomes the result of the attempt--that’s the risk one takes in pushing the limits!

Multiple rerolls may be granted from different @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edgesummarie00]{Edges}, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Bennies}, or other abilities.

Group Rolls

When the GM wants to make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Trait roll} for a group of Extras with like @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Traits}, roll one Trait die as usual along with a Wild Die and treat this as the group’s result. This gives a decent average without making rolls for every individual.

Example: A group of soldiers attempts to pass by an enemy encampment. The GM rolls their @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Stealth]{Stealth} die (a d6) and a Wild Die and takes the best of the two as the soldiers’ total.

Bennies

Every now and then, dice rolls may not work in your favor. That’s why Savage Pathfinder gives players a little control over their hero’s fate.

Player Character Bennies

Players start each game session with three “Bennies” (American slang for “benefits”), represented by poker chips, gaming stones, the official Bennies we make for all of our games, or other tokens that signify a little bit of good luck or fate. Bennies are discarded at the end of each session--use them or lose them!

Combat: If a session ends in the middle of combat or other dramatic event, wait until it’s resolved in the next session before giving out new Bennies.

GM Rewards: Bennies are earned during the game in two ways:

  • Awards: The Game Master should occasionally reward players for clever actions, roleplaying their character (especially any @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrancesum00]{Hindrances}), or great feats of heroism.
    She can also award players a Benny for telling a great story in character, delivering a fantastic line that makes everyone laugh, or creating an emotional moment.
  • Joker’s Wild: When a player character draws a Joker during combat, all player characters receive a Benny! If the players get both Jokers everyone gets two Bennies!

Game Master Bennies

Game Masters start each session with a pool of one Benny per player character. These may be used by any of her characters (including non-Wild Cards!).

The GM’s Wild Cards also have Bennies of their own, a base of three modified by their @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edgesummarie00]{Edges} and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrancesum00]{Hindrances}. They can use these or any of the Bennies in the common pool as the GM wishes.

  • Joker’s Wild: Anytime the villains draw a Joker, put one Benny in their general pool and give another to each enemy @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Card}.

Using Bennies

Bennies may be spent at any appropriate time and don’t incur any sort of penalty. They may only be used for your own character.

Here are the ways players can use Bennies.

  • Reroll a Trait: Bennies grant a hero a reroll on any Trait (see Rerolls, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{here}).
  • Recover from Shaken: This is instant and may be done at any time, even interrupting another’s actions if desired. See Shaken @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{here}.
  • Recover Power Points: A character with an Arcane Background, Mystic Powers, or any other ability that grants @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Points} can spend a Benny as a free action to recover five Power Points.
  • Soak Rolls: Bennies can be used to prevent @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} or recover from being Shaken.
  • Draw a New Action Card: When the game is in rounds, a character can spend a Benny to get a new @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Action Cards}. This occurs after all cards are dealt and@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edgesummarie00]{Edges} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrancesum00]{Hindrances} like @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Quick]{Quick}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Level Headed]{Level Headed}, or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Hesitant]{Hesitant} are resolved. Then players or the GM may spend Bennies for an additional card as many times as they like and take their choice of all their draws. Edges like Quick or Level Headed do not apply to these additional cards drawn with Bennies. This continues until everyone (including the GM) passes. Then the round begins and no further cards may be drawn.
  • Reroll Damage: You may spend a Benny to reroll damage. Include any additional dice you may have gained for a raise on the attack roll.
  • Influence the Story: This one is entirely up to the Game Master, who may allow a character to spend a Benny to find an additional clue if you’re stuck, come up with some mundane but needed item, or push a nonplayer character into being a bit more agreeable.

Example: The party is adrift on a storm-tossed sea. None of the characters purchased navigational equipment, but @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Harsk]{Harsk} the ranger had been aiding their doomed captain through the previous encounters. Harsk's player asks the Game Master if he might have been given his own compass and maps while aiding the captain, and might still have them in his bag. The GM agrees—for a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Benny}. Harsk suddenly remembers the tools in his pack and turns the boat toward shore.

Awarding Bennies

It takes a few games to figure out how many @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Bennies} you should award players during a session. In general, we recommend you be fairly free with them, especially early in the game. If someone makes everyone laugh (and isn’t distracting the flow of the game), toss the player a Benny. When players roleplay a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrancesum00]{Hindrance}, reward them. When someone does something clever or heroic or imaginative, acknowledge it with a Benny.

Some GMs worry the game will become too easy if Bennies are too common, but we find the opposite is true. When Bennies are plentiful, players often spend them on trivial things that are important to them. Maybe the rogue really wants to pick the lock on a chest. There’s nothing particularly valuable inside and the player probably knows it, but the character is the rogue and wants to prove it to the rest of the party.

When Bennies are scarce, however, players tend to save them for injuries, death, or taking out the big bads. That’s fine, but takes away from the fun and heroics that got them to this point. Savage Pathfinder is about big action and players should be encouraged to take chances. The “currency” of these chances are those Bennies.

Veteran Savage Worlds GMs might also notice Bennies tend to flow fairly fast early on in a session. The group is settling in, laughing, and are rewarded for roleplaying their Hindrances the first time or two. In the mid-to-late game, Bennies tend to be spent faster than they’re gained. That’s a fantastic pace. It gives the heroes opportunities to do big things in the early and mid-game then forces some critical resource management for the final showdown.

If you find yourself being stingy, go the other way the next time you run and see how it affects your group. Then you’ll know what’s right for you and your friends.

Conviction

Conviction is a special award granted when a character experiences a great and meaningful victory; or a painful and catastrophic misfortune. Either drives the hero to increase her efforts, giving her inner strength she can draw on in the most desperate situations.

Like @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Bennies}, players should receive a physical token of some sort to note their Conviction. The tokens can be spent at any time to add a d6 to all the character’s Trait and damage totals until the beginning of her next turn. This die can @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Ace}, and its result is added to the final total.

Conviction tokens don't stack, but the bonus may be maintained from round to round by spending a Benny at the start of the character's turn. Once Conviction lapses, however, the effect ends.

Conviction tokens aren’t Bennies and can’t be used as such. They are kept between sessions, however, and a hero can have more than one Conviction token at a time.

Refresh: A hero may also spend Conviction to trigger or refresh abilities that are usually only usable once per session, day, encounter, and so on, even if they’ve already been used.

Example: Tragedy & Triumph

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Seelah]{Seelah} the paladin of Iomedae and her companions signed on to escort a caravan from Turtleback Ferry to Sandpoint. Over the course of the journey, they made friends with the caravanners. Seelah became particularly close with a young girl she thought of as a daughter, Julia.

Then tragedy struck. A savage and brutal band of ogres descended from the hills and attacked the caravan. Seelah and her friends tore into the ogres with savage ferocity, but when the dust settled, Julia was found dead.

Given her close relationship with the girl, the Game Master decides Seelah's player gains Conviction. The paladin burns with rage at the murderous ogres and chastises herself for failing to protect her friend.

Later on, the party corners the ogres' chief in his hilltop fortress. Seelah personally defeats the brute in single combat and avenges Julia's death. The Game Master decides the paladin's triumph is also worthy of Conviction.

Combat.name: Combat
Combat.text:
Combat

Whether they’re the burning plains of the Cinderlands or the cursed battlefield of the Plain of Ten Thousand Swords--these are Savage Worlds and they are often violent.

The rest of this chapter tells you how great heroes and terrible monsters battle in Savage Pathfinder. The combat rules are designed for use with miniatures or pawns by default, but it’s easy to use these concepts when you’re playing without them.

Distance: Because the game assumes you are using terrain or a battlemat and standard 28mm miniatures, movement and weapon ranges are listed in inches. To translate that to regular distance, one inch equals two yards.

If you’re using miniatures and need to accommodate a larger battlefield, simply set each inch as five or 10 yards, for example, and adjust movement and ranges appropriately.

Time: When a fight breaks out, game time breaks down into rounds of about six seconds each. Ten rounds equal one minute.

  • Round: A “round” is an entire countdown of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Action Cards}, from the Ace to the Deuce (Two).
  • Turn: A character’s “turn” occurs when his Action Card comes up in the countdown. A hero with the Six of Diamonds, for example, takes his turn when that card comes up in the round.
  • Action: A single attack, skill use, etc. Characters may perform multiple actions on their turn (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Multi-Actions}).

Action Cards (Initiative)

The action in Savage Pathfinder is fast and furious. To help the Game Master keep track of who goes in what order and add a little randomness to the game, we use a single deck of playing cards with both Jokers left in to determine everyone’s initiative order. We call these “Action Cards.”

The GM can deal cards face up or face down as she sees fit. She might also deal the players’ cards face up and the villains face down to increase the players’ tension and uncertainty!

At the start of each round:

  • Deal each @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Card} an Action Card (plus any extra cards for @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edges}). Allies under a player’s control act on his Action Card.
  • Groups of nonplayer characters and creatures, such as all @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Zombie, Human]{zombies}, all @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Dog/wolf]{wolves}, and so on, should share an Action Card so they act together. This breaks each group up a bit for dramatic purposes and game balance and keeps things easy for the Game Master to manage.

Shuffle: Shuffle the deck after any round in which a Joker was dealt.

Large Groups: In very large groups or time-sensitive games, the Game Master can deal a single card per side (heroes and villains). On the heroes’ turn, simply start at one end of the group and work quickly around. This speeds things up if that’s more important than varying initiative order. If one or more characters have @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Level Headed]{Level Headed} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Quick]{Quick}, let that apply to the draw (but only once).

The Countdown

Once the cards are dealt, the Game Master starts the round by counting down from Ace down to Two, with each group resolving its actions when its card comes up.

Ties: Ties are resolved by suit order: Spades ♠ are first, then Hearts ♥, Diamonds ♦, and Clubs ♣. That’s reverse alphabetical order as used in many common card games.

  • Jokers: Characters (or groups) with a Joker act whenever they want in the round, even interrupting another’s action. They also add +2 to all @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Trait} and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{damage} rolls this round!

Actions

Characters perform “actions” when their @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Action Card} comes up each round. This is their “turn.” A character can move (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Movement}, below) and perform one regular action at any point in her movement, attacking, casting a spell, and so on, without penalty.

Characters can choose from a multitude of actions on their turn. Common actions include @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Supporting} allies, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Testing} foes, using a power, or attacking with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting}. See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Multi-Actions} to perform more than one action per turn (though only one of these can be a limited action).

More complex actions like lighting a torch or digging through a backpack might require more than a round to complete (GM’s call).

Free Actions

Speaking a short sentence or two, moving up to the character’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Pace}, falling @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{prone}, or dropping an item are all free actions. A hero can generally perform several free actions on her turn simultaneously (speaking and dropping an item while walking, for example), though only one of these can be a limited free action (see below). The GM decides how much is too much.

Some free actions occur automatically at the beginning of a character’s turn and may only be tried once, such as recovering from being @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} or "@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned}.

Free actions that are “reactions,” such as resisting @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{opposed rolls} or powers, occur each time the situation presents itself.

Limited Actions

Some actions are so complex or involved they require greater concentration. A character may only perform one limited action on their turn. It may be part of a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Multi-Action} as usual.

Limited Free Actions

A character may only perform one limited free action per turn. For example, the barbarian’s @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Intimidating Glare]{Intimidating Glare} allows her to make an @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation} Test as a limited free action. If the barbarian also had access to another limited free action, she could not do it in the same turn as she used Intimidating Glare.

Movement

Characters can move a number of tabletop inches equal to their Pace each turn, and may freely set their facing as they do so.

Each inch of movement spent climbing, crawling, or swimming uses 2″ of Pace.

Running: A hero can “run” as a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{free action} once per turn, increasing her Pace for the round by her running die (a d6 by default) at the cost of a −2 penalty to all other actions that turn. Running dice never Ace. (The running die is random to account for nuances of terrain not depicted on the tabletop and for the “risk to reward” decision players must make.)

Out of combat situations, a character can move twice the sum of her full Pace + maximum running die for a number of minutes equal to half her Vigor die type. Thus a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Fleet-Footed]{Fleet-Footed} character with Vigor d6 can sprint at a Pace of 32 for three minutes.

Difficult Ground: Each inch a hero moves over rough terrain such as thick forest, up or down a steep incline, slippery ice, etc., counts as 2″ of her Pace. Crawling is unaffected by Difficult Ground.

Hazards: If the GM feels movement is hazardous for some reason--climbing under duress, swimming a fast-moving river, walking a tightrope--she can require an @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll to move. Success means she continues on normally. Failure means she can’t move. With a "@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Critical Failure} the character takes @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Fatigue} from Bumps & Bruises, falls if climbing or in a precarious position (see Falling), or drowns if swimming (see Drowning) both in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{Hazards}.

Other Movement Issues

  • Jumping: Characters can jump 1″ (two yards) horizontally, or 0.5″ vertically as a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{free action}. Double these numbers if the hero can run at least 2″ (four yards) prior to the jump. If the hero chooses, she may make an @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll as an action to increase her horizontal distance by 1″ (2″ with a raise), or half that vertically. Jumping does not allow a character to exceed her total Pace for the turn.
  • Prone: A hero may fall @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{prone} as a free action during her turn. She may crawl while prone (see above). Standing is a free action but reduces total Pace for the turn by 2.

Attacks

The basics of fast, furious combat are discussed below. Many additional options and situations are covered under Situational Rules @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{here}.

Melee Attacks

The Target Number to hit an opponent is equal to his @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Parry} (2 plus half his Fighting die type; 2 if he has no Fighting skill).

Ranged Attacks

The @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} skill covers everything from bows to crossbows and even some magic items that shoot projectiles. Throwing knives, spears, and other thrown projectiles uses the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} skill.

All ranged weapons have a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Range} statistic written like this: 5/10/20, or Short/Medium/Long Range.

Range penalties
