The base Target Number to hit something at Short Range is 4. Firing at longer ranges inflicts the penalties listed above.

Extreme Range: Extreme Range is up to 4× a weapon’s Long Range. Firing at such a great distance requires the Aim option. When used in this way, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Aim} doesn’t reduce any penalties--it simply allows the character to fire at Extreme Range.

Characters may not throw weapons at Extreme Range.

Rate of Fire: Rate of Fire is how many shots (Shooting dice) a ranged weapon can fire in one action. A longbow with a RoF of 1, for example, can fire one shot per action. For weapons with a Rate of Fire 2 or more, declare how many shots you are firing. Then roll that number of Shooting dice and assign them in whatever order you like to the chosen targets.

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Cards} roll their Shooting dice plus a single Wild Die, which can replace any one Shooting die if desired.

Damage

After a successful melee or ranged hit, the attacker rolls damage. Ranged weapons do fixed damage as listed in the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Gear} section. Most bows, for example, cause 2d6 damage.

Hand weapons cause damage equal to the attacker’s Strength die plus a second die, which depends on the weapon. A barbarian with a d12 Strength and a long sword (d8 damage) rolls d12+d8 damage. Add the rolls on the damage dice together to get the damage total.

Even though Strength is used to determine melee damage, this isn’t a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Trait} roll so @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Cards} don’t add a Wild Die to the roll.

All damage rolls can @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Ace}.

Unarmed Damage: An unarmed combatant rolls only his Strength die unless he has an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edge} like "@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Brawler]{Brawler} that grants him a damage die.

Bonus Damage

Well-placed attacks are more likely to hit vital areas and do more damage. If your hero gets a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise} on his attack roll (regardless of how many raises), he adds +1d6 to the final total. Bonus dice can also @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Ace!}

Bonus damage applies to all attacks, including spells and area effect weapons.

Applying Damage

If the damage roll is less than the target’s Toughness, the victim is beaten up a bit but there’s no game effect. If the damage is equal to or greater than his Toughness, he’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}. Each raise on the damage roll also inflicts a Wound:

  • Success: The character is Shaken. If he was already Shaken and the second result is from physical damage of some kind (not a Test that results in Shaken, for example), he remains and takes a Wound.
  • Raise: The character suffers a Wound for every raise on the damage roll, and is Shaken.

Damage Effects

Damage can result in three effects: @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds}, and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitation}.

Shaken

Shaken characters are nicked, bruised, or otherwise rattled. They may only take @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{free actions}, such as moving (including running). At the start of their turn, Shaken characters must attempt to recover from being Shaken by making a Spirit roll. This is a free action.

  • Failure: The character remains Shaken. She can only perform free actions.
  • Success: The character is no longer Shaken and may act normally.

Bennies: A player may spend a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Benny} at any time to remove her Shaken status (even when it’s not her turn).

Wounds

Every raise on the damage roll inflicts a Wound. Extras are @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated} if they take a single Wound (and aren’t @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Resilient]{Resilient}). They’re dead, injured, or otherwise out of the fight.

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Cards} can take three Wounds and still function (more with certain @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edges} or abilities). Further damage doesn’t cause additional Wounds but Incapacitates them instead.

Wound Penalties: Each Wound a character suffers causes a −1 cumulative penalty to his Pace (minimum of 1″) and all @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Trait} rolls--up to a maximum penalty of −3.

Timing: Characters sometimes take multi­ple hits on the same @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Action Card}. Resolve each damage roll separately before moving on to the next (including any Soak rolls).

Wound Cap

In Savage Pathfinder, characters can never suffer more than four @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} in a single hit and therefore never have to Soak more than four wounds either. This rule keeps combat dangerous but reduces the chances of heroes (and villains!) dying from a single lucky blow. It can still happen, but it is far more rare.

Ignore the cap for catastrophic damage such as falls from great heights, extreme environments such as lava, and so on.

Large Creatures: The Wound Cap still applies to large or Resilient creatures with more than three Wounds. A Huge dragon that can take five Wounds before being @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}, for example, can’t take more than four from a single attack, so it can’t be killed with a single attack even if it fails to Soak.

Incapacitation

Incapacitated characters may not perform actions but are still dealt @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Action Cards} for the remainder of the encounter in case they recover or must roll for other effects such as Bleeding Out (below). @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edges} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrances0000]{Hindrances} that affect card draws, such as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Quick]{Quick}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Level Headed]{Level Headed}, or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Hesitant]{Hesitant} are ignored when the hero is Incapacitated.

If Incapacitated by damage or injury, he must make an immediate Vigor roll:

  • Critical Failure: The character dies.
  • Failure: Roll on the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-tables.Injury]{Injury Table}. The Injury is permanent and the character is Bleeding Out, see Bleeding Out below.
  • Success: Roll on the Injury Table. The Injury goes away when all @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} are healed.
  • Raise: Roll on the Injury Table. The Injury goes away in 24 hours, or when all Wounds are healed (whichever is sooner).

Characters cannot take actions of any kind and might be unconscious (GM’s call). The victim makes a Vigor roll each day thereafter and is no longer @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}(or unconscious) if successful. They may also heal Wounds during this time (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03healing0000000]{Natural Healing}).

Bleeding Out: The injured character is dying and must make a Vigor roll at the start of his turn. Failure means he perishes. With success he survives but must roll again next turn (or every minute if not in combat). With a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise}, he stabilizes and no further rolls are required.

Other characters may stop a victim’s bleeding by making a Healing roll (the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Healing]{skill} or the spell). This is an action, and if successful the patient is stabilized.

The @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Healing]{healing} power can also stabilize Wounds, as can a successful “natural” healing roll by a being with regeneration of some sort.

More on Shaken

Figuring out how @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} work together takes a little getting used to, but is worth it for the game play it provides. In essence, it means Shaking an Extra twice usually takes it off the table. It gets a bit more complicated with @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Card} or creatures that can take more than one Wound, so here’s a table that might help.

Examples:

  • A character takes a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound}. She’s also @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}.
  • A character is Shaken, then takes a Wound. She has one Wound and remains Shaken.
  • A character is already Shaken, then Shaken again (without a Wound). She now has one Wound and remains Shaken.
  • A character has two Wounds and is Shaken. She takes another Wound, so she has three Wounds and remains Shaken.

Soak Rolls

After taking damage but before applying any Wounds, the defender may spend a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Bennies} to make a “Soak” roll. This is a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} check, with each success and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise} reducing the number of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} suffered from that attack by one.

If the character Soaks all of the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} from an attack, he removes his @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} condition too (even from a previous source). Don’t count the Wound modifiers he’s about to suffer when making this roll--that hasn’t happened yet.

Characters can’t Soak more than once per attack, but may spend @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Bennies} as usual to reroll the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} check if they aren’t satisfied with the results.

Shaken: A character can spend a Benny to immediately eliminate a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} condition. This is instant and can be done at any time.

Healing.name: Healing
Healing.text:
Healing

The @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Healing]{Healing} skill is used to remove @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{wounds}. Each attempt requires 10 minutes per wound level of the patient. Subtract 1 from Healing rolls without a basic healer's kit or similar supplies.

A success removes one Wound, and a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise} removes two. Failure means no Wounds are removed. A @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Critical Failure} increases the victim’s Wound level by one.

The Golden Hour: A character may only attempt to heal Wounds on a patient once within the hour they were sustained. Failing the roll means the healer isn’t able to treat those particular injuries. A different character may attempt a Healing roll on the same patient, however.

Once the Wounds are over an hour old, only @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03healing0000000]{natural healing} or the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Healing]{healing} power (using greater healing) can heal Wounds.

Bleeding Out: The Healing skill can also be used to stabilize someone who’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03healing0000000]{Bleeding Out} . Each attempt is an action, and if successful the victim is stabilized.

Incapacitation: Healing at least one Wound on an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated} patient removes that state (and restores consciousness if he was knocked out).

Natural Healing

Wounded characters make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll every five days. Success recovers one @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound}, and a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise} recovers two.

A @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Critical Failure} increases the victim’s Wound level by one-- either from infection, blood loss, or aggravating the injuries. If this causes @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitation}, don’t use the usual rules for taking damage. Instead, the victim lapses in and out of consciousness and makes a Vigor roll every 12 hours. If the roll is failed, he expires. Success means he must roll again 12 hours later. With a raise he stabilizes and wakes. Allies may also attempt to stabilize the hero as explained under @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03healing0000000]{Bleeding Out}.

Support: Don’t forget to use @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Support} when your party has been beaten up a bit. Characters with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Healing]{Healing}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Survival]{Survival}, or other skills can make Support rolls to help allies make their Vigor rolls to heal!

Aftermath & Extras

If it’s important to know what happens to Extras who were @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated} during a fight, make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll for each. Those who succeed survive and must be cared for, taken prisoner, or released. This can present interesting challenges for your heroes in the aftermath of savage combat!

The Golden Hour

Patients who survive their initial trauma have about an hour to survive most life-threatening injuries. If they receive medical attention during that time, they can generally be saved. The longer the wait, however, the more likely the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} are to be fatal.

In Savage Pathfinder, we extend this concept to healing in general. Besides reflecting the real-world concept, it also provides good game balance and drama as the party has to decide whether to press on despite their injuries.

Situational Rules.name: Situational Rules
Situational Rules.text:
Situational rules

The core rules for Pathfinder for Savage Worlds are very simple— roll a skill die (and a Wild Die if a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Card)}. If the result is 4 or higher after all modifiers, you’re successful.

In the following section are some of the more elaborate maneuvers characters can attempt.

Aim

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} rolls assume a character is moving about, dodging attacks, and keeping an eye on the chaos around her. If she focuses her attention and aims, she can make a much more accurate shot.

If a character spends her entire turn Aiming a ranged weapon at a particular target or spot (GM's call) and takes no other actions, on her next turn she may ignore up to 4 points of"@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Range}, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Cover}, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Called Shot}, or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Scale} penalties; or add +2 to her roll. Her attack must be used on the first action of her next turn or the bonus is lost.

The shooter must be relatively stationary to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Aim}. She can’t walk, run, ride a horse, or be constantly jostled.

Area Effect Attacks

Spell effects, breath weapons, and other attacks that cover a large area are “area effect attacks”. The most common are Small, Medium, and Large Blast Templates, and the Cone and Stream Templates. There are copies you can print out on our website.

Area effect weapons target a location rather than individuals and so ignore defensive bonuses for targets covered by the template, such as the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Dodge]{Dodge} Edge or speed penalties.

Cone and Stream templates are placed with one end (usually the narrow end for the cone template) emanating from the attacker and fired with the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} skill (or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} for breath weapons and other natural attacks). A basic success means those beneath the template are hit. Failure means the attack didn’t occur for some reason— the creature failed to belch up noxious gas, the flamethrower malfunctioned, etc.

To attack with a blast template, the player places it on the tabletop (or describes where he wants it to land) and rolls Shooting, or Athletics for thrown weapons and breath attacks. If the attack fails and there’s a chance the miss might hit someone else, see Deviation, below.

If the roll is successful, any target even partially beneath the template is affected, regardless of any attack penalties to hit such as the Dodge Edge. If the effect causes damage, roll for each victim separately. Attacks that hit with a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise} cause bonus damage as usual.

Deviation

Most of the time, the GM can ignore a missed @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{area effect attack}. If it's important to know where a missed blast lands, thrown items deviate 1d6″. Fired projectiles deviate 2d6". Multiply by 2 if the attack was made at Medium Range, 3 if Long, and 4 for Extreme.

Next roll a d12 and read it like a clock facing to determine the direction the missile deviates. A weapon can never deviate more than half the distance to the original target (that keeps it from going behind the thrower).

Template Diameter Targets Affected
Small 4 yards 2
Medium 8 yards 3
Large 12 yards 4
Cone 18-yard-long cone 3
Stream 24 × 2-yard line 3

Templates Without Miniatures

Use the measurements below when you need to figure out how many enemies a template might affect and you aren't using miniatures.

The Targets Affected column above shows the GM how many enemies are hit in narrative situations, modifying the result if the targets are spread out (like trained assassins) or bunched up (like mindless zombies).

Cover and Area Effect Attacks

Solid obstacles like trees or thick walls protect against @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{area effect attacks} if they’re between the center of the blast and a victim and the GM thinks they’d offer protection. Reduce the damage by half the object's hardness, see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Cover & Obstacles}.

Bound and Entangled

Grappling and powers like @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Entangle]{entangle} cause characters to be Bound and Entangled. Here’s what each of those states means and how to break free from them. Characters are either @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Bound or Entangled}— effects don't stack.

  • Entangled: The victim can’t move and is Distracted as long as he remains Entangled.
  • Bound: The victim may not move, is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Distracted and Vulnerable} as long as he remains Bound, and cannot make physical actions other than trying to break free.

Breaking free is an action. With success, an Entangled hero is free of one particular entanglement or grappler. A Bound character improves to Entangled with a success; with a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise}, he’s free. See below for more details:

Breaking Free from a Foe: Use the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Grappling} rules in reverse to break free. The victim initiates an opposed @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll with whoever’s holding him (either may roll Strength at −2 instead to maintain or break free of the hold). If the victim’s successful, she improves her status one level, or two with a raise.

A @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} grappler maintains her hold. @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned} grapplers let go immediately.

Breaking Free from a Device: Escaping a web, net, or the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Entangle]{entangle} power is a Strength −2 roll or Athletics roll (victim’s choice) minus any penalties noted for the entanglement. The sticky web of a giant spider, for example, might note that escape attempts are made at −2 or more. This is an action, and success works just like breaking free from a foe (explained above).

Characters and allies may also destroy the entanglement (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Breaking Things}. Webs, ropes, nets, and the like are generally Hardness 4 and must be cut with an edged weapon.

Breaking Things

Occasionally a character may want to break a solid object, such as a weapon, lock, or door. Use the wielder’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Parry} if held, or 2 if it’s motionless. If a damage roll equals or exceeds the object’s Hardness, it’s broken, bent, shattered, or otherwise ruined. The GM decides the exact effect.

Most anything can be broken given enough time and effort, so use this system only when attempting to break things in a hurry (such as during combat rounds).

Object Hardness
Hardness Object
4 Rope
6 Bow
8 Polearm, thin wooden door or wall
10 Shield*, longsword, thick wooden door or wall
12 Iron lock, manacles, shackles

*A character must specifically state he’s trying to break a shield to do so—don’t check every time the shield-bearer is hit.

No Bonus Damage or Aces: Attacks against solid objects don’t get bonus damage from @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raises}, and damage rolls don’t @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Ace}. Unlike a person or complex device like a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02vehicles000000]{vehicle}, an attack can’t hit a “vital” area on a lock or a door and thus do more damage.

Damage Types: Certain types of attacks can’t break certain types of objects. A club can’t cut a rope, for example. Use common sense when determining whether or not a particular type of weapon can destroy an object.

Called Shots

Targeting a particular part of the body is a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Called Shot}. The modifier to the attack roll depends on the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Scale} of the target itself (not the creature it’s part of). Use the Scale Modifiers table in the Size and Scale section further down to determine any bonus or penalty for the target’s Scale. These modifiers are already listed in parentheses for Normal scale creatures, along with any specific game effects:

  • Hand (-4): Target may be @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Disarmed}.
  • Head or Vitals (-4): Hitting the head or vital organs of living creatures adds +4 damage to the attacker’s total. The penalty is −5 if attempting to target the face of someone wearing an open-faced helmet (thus bypassing the helmet’s Armor).
  • Item(?) : Use the dimensions on the Scale table for items. Targeting something the size of a dagger, for example, is −4.
  • Limbs(-2) Unless attempting to Disarm (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{here}), hitting a limb has no additional special effect since it’s already accounted for by Wound and Pace penalties (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{here}).
  • Unarmored Area (?) : The attack targets the unprotected area of a target otherwise covered in Armor. The penalty depends on the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Scale} of the area. The eye slit of a helmet is Tiny (−6), for example, while the flesh beneath the missing scale of a Huge dragon might be Very Small (−4).

Chases

Whether a daring rooftop chase in the dead of night or a desperate escape through an ill-lit dungeon, a chase can be played out like a regular combat, or using a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04quickencount00]{Quick Encounter}. Or you can check out our Narrative Chase Deck to resolve the action.

Cover and Obstacles

Melee and ranged attacks suffer a penalty when attempting to hit a target behind @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Cover}. Penalties only apply to the targeted area— a skeleton standing behind a knee-high wall doesn't get Light Cover, but he does if a quarter of his body is protected by a door frame.

Cover Penalties
Penalty Cover
−2 Light Cover: A quarter of the target is obscured.
−4 Medium Cover: Half the target is obscured, or target is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{prone}.
−6 Heavy Cover: Three-quarters of the target is obscured.
−8 Near Total Cover: The target is hidden or barely visible.

Obstacles

Sometimes characters have sufficient power to attack their foes through obstacles. (See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Breaking Things} to actually destroy intervening obstacles.)

When this happens, add an Armor bonus equal to half the obstacle's Hardness to the target beyond (round up if necessary).

If the obstacle is a person or creature, subtract its Toughness from the attack instead.

Defend

A character can choose to focus all her energy and skill into defense against melee attacks with the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Defend} maneuver. This increases her @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Parry} by +4 and takes her entire turn— she cannot perform @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Multi-Actions}. She may move normally but may not run. The bonus lasts until the beginning of her next turn.

Desperate Attack

Determined to land a blow, the warrior unleashes a frantic attack, focusing on hitting his target at the expense of damage. He adds +2 or +4 to any Fighting roll and subtracts a like amount from damage if he hits. This can be determined per attack (before rolling), and can't be combined with @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wild Attack}.

Disarm

A character can try to make an opponent drop a weapon or other object by making an attack against the limb or hand (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Called Shot}). If the attack hits a weapon, the attacker rolls damage normally for an item (no raise effect or Aces, see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Breaking Things}). The defender must make a Strength roll equal to the damage or drop the item.

If an attack against a target's hand or limb @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shakes} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} him, he must make a Strength roll at −2 if it hit his limb or −4 if it hit his hand. Failure means he drops whatever item is in that hand.

Distracted and Vulnerable

Characters may be @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Distracted or made Vulnerable} by special abilities, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Tests}, or powers. These states last until the end of the character’s next turn unless otherwise noted. If a hero becomes Distracted or Vulnerable during her current turn, it lasts until the end of her next turn. Like effects don't stack.

  • Distracted: The hero subtracts 2 from all @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Trait} rolls until the end of his next turn.
  • Vulnerable: Actions and attacks against the target are made at +2 until the end of his next turn. This doesn’t stack with The Drop (see below).

The Drop

Sometimes an attacker is able to catch a foe off-guard and gets “The Drop” on him. The GM decides when this is in effect— usually it’s when the victim is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{bound} or completely unaware of an attack. The Drop usually happens up close but the GM can also allow it in other situations as she sees fit (a sniper attacking an unaware and stationary target).

The Drop adds +4 to a character’s attack and damage rolls against that target for one action.

Knockout Blow: If a character takes enough damage to be @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} or worse from an attacker with The Drop on him, he must make a Vigor roll (at −2 if the attack was to the head) or be knocked unconscious.

KO’ed characters stay that way for about half an hour or until the GM decides it’s dramatically appropriate to wake up. Note that Knockout Blows come from any kind of damage, not just blows to the head!

Evasion

Some attacks are slow or require the user to “telegraph” their delivery, like flamethrowers or dragon’s breath. Such attacks state they may be Evaded. If an attack doesn’t say it can be Evaded, it can’t— victims are simply hit if the attack is successful and take damage.

If an attack can be Evaded and the character is aware of it, he makes an Agility roll at −2. Those who are successful manage to avoid the attack and take no damage. If this was an area effect attack, the GM should place the figure to the side or rear of the template as makes sense in the situation.

Fatigue

Some hazards, stress, powers, or circum­stances may cause Fatigue instead of damage. This represents mental stress or minor but lingering injuries that make a person less effective. Fatigue stacks until the victim is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}.

  • Fatigued: The victim subtracts 1 from all @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Trait} rolls. If he takes another level of Fatigue, he’s Exhausted.
  • Exhausted: The victim subtracts 2 from all Trait rolls. If he takes another level of Fatigue, he’s Incapacitated.
  • Incapacitated: The victim cannot perform actions and may be unconscious (GM’s call).

Recovery

Unless otherwise specified by the source, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Fatigue} and Exhaustion improve one level per hour. Characters @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated} from Fatigue are helpless and may be unconscious (GM’s call) for 2d6 hours. If treatment is possible (food, water, etc.; depending on the source of Fatigue), and a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Healing]{Healing} roll is made, the character improves to Exhausted.

Mixed Fatigue: If a hero suffers Fatigue from different sources with different recovery times, remove one level when the effect with the shortest duration expires, then another level when the longest expires.

Hazards

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Fatigue} from hunger, thirst, etc., sometimes has different recovery conditions. See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{Hazards}.

Finishing Move

A completely helpless victim may be dispatched with a lethal weapon of some sort as an action. This is automatic unless the GM decides there’s a special situation, such as a particularly tough or naturally armored victim, a chance for escape, and so on.

The killer must usually dispatch his foe up close and personal, but the GM may occasionally let @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Finishing Moves} be performed at range if the situation warrants.

Firing Into Melee

Occasionally, heroes have to fire into the middle of hand-to-hand fights. The trouble is that even though we might see figures standing perfectly still on the tabletop, in “reality,” they’re circling each other, wrestling back and forth, and moving erratically. For that reason, firing into a tangle of people, such as a melee, is quite dangerous. Use the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Innocent Bystander} rules when this occurs.

Free Attacks

Some Edges, such as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Counterattack]{Counterattack} and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.First Strike]{First Strike}, or options such as @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Withdrawing From Melee}, allow a character to make a free attack.

Free attacks are a single attack unaltered by other Edges or combat options. This is usually a Fighting or grappling attack, but could include Shooting if the attacker is armed with a hand crossbow, wand, or small device (GM's call, see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Ranged Weapons in Melee}.

Ganging Up

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Ganging Up} allows attackers to flank, exploit openings, and generally harass a foe. Each additional adjacent ally (who isn’t @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned}) adds +1 to all the attackers’ Fighting rolls, up to a maximum of +4. If three goblins attack a single hero, for example, each of the three goblins add +2 to their Fighting rolls.

Each of the defender's adjacent allies cancels out one point of Gang Up bonus from an attacker adjacent to both. This means troops in opposing lines, such as a medieval formation where each man has three adjacent foes and two adjacent allies, don’t get the bonus unless actually flanked.

Grappling

As an action, an attacker can make an opposed @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll to grapple a defender. If the attacker wins, the foe is Entangled. With a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise}, he’s Bound. (Success on a foe who was already Entangled makes him Bound.) See@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Bound & Entangled}.

If a foe is Bound, the grappler is also @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Vulnerable} while maintaining his hold.

The @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Gang Up} bonus applies when grappling a defender, but other maneuvers don’t unless the Game Master rules otherwise in a specific situation.

Size Matters: If there’s a difference in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Scale} between the attacker and defender, the grappler subtracts the difference from his total (the defender doesn't get a bonus or penalty for Scale difference).

Creatures may not generally grapple a foe more than two Sizes larger than themselves unless they have exceptional reach or Strength for their Size (GM’s call).

Example: A dragon (Huge +4) tries to pin a humanoid thief (Normal). The difference between Huge and Normal Scales is 4, so the dragon must subtract 4 from its @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll. The rogue doesn't get a bonus or penalty.

Crush: A grappler may harm someone he’s Entangled or Bound by making an opposed Strength roll as an action on his turn. With success, his attack does his Strength in damage (gaining bonus damage for a raise as normal).

Hold

A hero may choose to delay her turn by going on "Hold". This allows her to resolve her actions later in the round if she wishes, and lasts until it’s used. If a character is on Hold when a new round begins, she’s not dealt a new Action Card but can go at any point in the round she chooses. (Discard her current card and mark her as “On Hold” with a counter of some sort.)

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned}: If a character is Shaken or Stunned while on Hold, she immediately loses her Hold status and her turn for the round. (Shaken or Stunned characters can’t go on Hold either.)

Interrupting Actions: If a character on Hold wants to interrupt an action (including a rival who was also on Hold), she and the opponent make opposed @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} rolls. Whoever rolls highest goes first. In the rare case of a tie, the actions are simultaneous.

If the character interrupting fails, she loses her Hold status but gets a turn after the foe finishes his. She may take whatever actions she wishes when her turn comes up— she’s not locked into whatever she was trying to do when she failed to interrupt.

Illumination

Darkness conceals details and makes it more difficult to detect objects and targets. Subtract the Illumination Penalties (see the Illumination Penalties table below) from active @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Trait} rolls affected by Illumination, such as attacks, arcane skill and Notice rolls, etc.

It’s up to the Game Master exactly what Trait rolls are affected, but here are a few examples of rolls that should not be penalized:

  • Resisting powers
  • Resisting grappling attempts
  • Recovering from a negative status, such as being Shaken or Stunned
  • Verbal Support rolls
  • Verbal Tests
  • A friendly, cooperative, adjacent character in Pitch Darkness where touch and communication overcome lack of sight

Note that foes may get bonuses for attacking a target that can’t see them (see Attacking from Stealth in the Stealth subsection in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Traits}).

ILLUMINATION PENALTIES
Penalty Lighting
−2 Dim: Twilight, light fog, night with a full moon. Visibility is generally limited to 25" (50 yards).
−4 Dark: Typical night conditions with some ambient light from stars, a clouded or partial moon, a few flickering torches in a large space, etc. Targets aren’t visible outside of 10″.
−6 Pitch Darkness: Complete and total darkness (or the target is hidden or invisible). Powers that require sight may not be possible.

Improvised Weapons

Heroes often fight with objects that aren’t intended for use as weapons. Torches, vases, chairs, tankards, bottles, tools, and other mundane items are frequently pressed into service in combat.

Characters with improvised weapons count as armed but subtract 2 from attack rolls. Range, damage and Minimum Strength are determined by type:

  • Light: Beer stein, fist-sized rock, dagger pommel (as a club). Range 3/6/12, Damage Str+d4, Min Str d4.
  • Medium: Hammer, pick, wooden chair. Range 2/4/8, Damage Str+d6, Min. Str d6.
  • Heavy: Head-size rock, sack of stones, log. Range 1/2/4, Damage Str+d8, Min. Str d8.

The GM should adjust the damage and other factors as makes sense for the particular item.

Innocent Bystanders

When an attacker misses a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (throwing) roll, it may sometimes be important to see if any other targets in the line of fire were hit. The GM should only use this rule when it’s dramatically appropriate— not for every missed shot in a hail of arrows.

Each skill die that’s a 1 hits a random victim adjacent to or directly in the line of fire to the original target.

A @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Card} must miss with his Wild Die for a RoF 1 weapon to hit an Innocent Bystander— wild dice never hit innocent bystanders.

This sometimes means it's easier to hit an adjacent victim than the original target. That may not be entirely realistic, but is simple, dramatic, and requires some care in tight tactical situations.

  • RoF 2+: Although rare on Golarion, weapons with a Rate of Fire or 2 or more, or that fire in a spread, are much more likely to hit others. Each skill die that rolls a 1 or a 2 hits a bystander.

Mounted Combat

Characters fighting from horseback (or other beasts) have certain advantages and disadvantages in combat, as described below.

Mounts aren’t dealt Action Cards— they act with their riders. Animals may attack during their rider’s action if desired.

Horsemanship: Characters who wish to fight from horseback must use the lowest of their @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Riding]{Riding} skills. This also applies to other more extraordinary mounts.

Falling: If a character is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned}, or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} while mounted, or his mount is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}, he must make a Riding roll. If he fails, he falls. If the mount was running, the rider suffers 2d4 damage (2d6 with a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Critical Failure}). Increase the damage by an additional die or two if the mount is particularly fast, flies, or the rider falls in particularly rough or dangerous terrain.

Missed Ranged Attacks: Mounts and riders are affected by the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Innocent Bystander} rules. If a shot intended at a rider rolls a 1, it hits the mount instead.

Wounded Mounts: When an animal is Shaken or Wounded, it rears or bucks. A rider must make a Riding roll to stay mounted, or falls as above.

Charging

A rider on a charging mount adds +4 to his damage roll with a successful Fighting attack. To be considered charging, the rider must have moved at least 5″ (10 yards) or more in a relatively straight line toward his foe.

Setting Weapons: A weapon with a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Reach} of 1 or greater can be “set” against a cavalry attack. To do so, the attacker must be on @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Hold} and win an opposed @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll to interrupt as usual. Whoever has the most Reach adds +2 to his roll.

The winner attacks first. If successful, he adds the +4 charge bonus to his damage (whether he’s the rider or not).

Multi-Actions

Characters can perform up to three actions on their turn (one of which may be a limited action). Each additional action beyond the first inflicts a −2 penalty to all actions. Taking two actions, for example, incurs a −2 penalty to both, and three actions is a −4 penalty.

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Cards} get their Wild Die on each action as usual.

All actions must be declared at the start of the turn and before any dice are rolled. Penalties remain even if a later action doesn’t happen (usually because it was dependent on an earlier success).

Movement and Multiple Actions: A hero may take her actions at different points of her movement as she wishes.

Free Actions: @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Multi-Action} penalties do not apply to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{free} (or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{limited free}) actions.

Natural Weapons

Creatures with natural weapons such as fangs, claws, or horns may attack with them using their @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} skill. Damage is stated for character @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01ancestries0000]{ancestries} and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08bestiary000000]{beasts} in their various descriptions.

Creatures with natural weapons are always considered armed. This means they aren’t @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Unarmed Defenders} and foes fighting with @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Two Weapons} gain no advantage against them. Here are a few additional notes for each type of attack:

  • Bite: The creature may bite a target it’s grappled (most attackers can only crush their prey, see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Grappling}. This is a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} attack.
  • Claws: Add +2 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (climbing) rolls on any rough or soft surface (not sheer steel, glass, etc.).
  • Horns: Add +4 damage from a successful attack with a creature's horns if it runs and moves at least 5″(10 yards).

Nonlethal Damage

A character who wants to beat someone up without killing them can choose to do nonlethal damage. This requires the attacker use only his fists or a blunt weapon of some sort. Edged weapons may be used if they have a flat side, but this subtracts −1 from the attacker’s @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} rolls.

Nonlethal damage causes Wounds as usual, but if a character is rendered @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}, he cannot Bleed out.

Off-Hand Attacks

Characters are assumed to be right-handed unless the player decides otherwise. Actions that require precise eye-hand coordination, such as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting}, suffer a −2 penalty when done solely with the off-hand.

Off-hand weapons don’t add their @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Parry} bonus unless the hero is @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Ambidextrous]{Ambidextrous}.

Prone

Ranged attacks suffer a −4 penalty to hit prone characters from a range of 3″ (6 yards) or greater (this does not stack with @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Cover}) and subtract four points of damage from @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Area Effect attacks}.

If a prone defender is caught in melee, his @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Parry} is reduced by 2 and he must subtract 2 from his @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} rolls.

Standing from prone is a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{free action}, but costs a character 2″ of movement.

Push

Sometimes characters may want to push a foe in hopes of knocking him out of position, prone, or even into a deadly hazard.

Pushing a foe is an action that requires opposed roll of Strength. If the attacker is successful he pushes the foe back 1″ (two yards), or twice that with a raise.

A character who’s successfully Pushed must make an @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll (at −2 if the attacker got a raise) or be knocked @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{prone}.

Running: If the attacker runs at least 2″ (four yards) before the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Push}, he adds +2 to his total.

Size Matters: Double the distance pushed if the attacker’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Scale} is larger than the foe’s. Creatures may not generally Push a foe more than two Sizes larger then themselves unless they have exceptional Strength for their Size (GM’s call).

Skill: The attacker or defender may roll Athletics instead of Strength if they choose.

Shields: Attackers and defenders add their shield’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Parry} bonus to their Strength (or Athletics) rolls when pushing.

Ranged Weapons in Melee

Heroes may fire ranged weapons when engaged in melee with a few caveats:

  • The attacker may only use a power or a one-handed ranged weapon (such as a thrown dagger) when in melee. He may not fire two-handed weapons such as a bow. The TN is the defender’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Parry} instead of Short Range as he struggles back and forth, etc.
  • If attacking a non-adjacent target with a ranged attack while in melee, the attacker instantly becomes @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Vulnerable}.

Readying Weapons

Characters may “ready” up to two items per turn as a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{free action}. Readying means drawing, holstering, or otherwise moving an item into or out of an easy-to-reach location.

Each additional item readied is an action, as is recovering an item from a difficult location like an ankle sheath, off the floor after being disarmed, or other exten­uating circumstances.

Reloading

Nocking an arrow or loading a sling is a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{free action}, but reloading any ranged weapon requires two hands (thrown weapons are readied, see above).

Some weapons, like heavy crossbows, are slower to reload. They require a number of actions to reload, listed as “Reload X” in their description.

Example: Our ranger fires a heavy crossbow (Reload 2) as part of a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Multi-Action}, using his other two actions that turn to reload. Since this is three actions, his @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} roll is made at −4. On his next turn, he's ready to fire again.

Running & Reloading: Running and loading requires an Agility roll (at the usual −2 penalty for running). Failure means no progress toward reloading was made that action.

Rest

Whenever a party decides to rest for a prolonged period (at least eight hours of no activity), each @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Card} in the party recovers one @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Benny}. Of course, the party's enemies are able to regather their strength, too, so the GM also regains a Benny.

Size and Scale

Characters and creatures have a Size ranging from −4 for very small beings up to Size 20 and higher for massive behemoths. Specific creature Sizes are listed in their statistics, and explained on the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size Table}.

The Size Table lists seven different “Scales,” from Tiny to Gargantuan, and the Scale Modifier that goes with each.

When creatures of different Scales attack each other, the smaller creature adds the difference between its Scale and its target to its attacks. A Tiny fairy (−6 Scale modifier), for example, adds +10 to attack a Huge dragon (+4). The larger creature subtracts the difference from its attacks. A Very Small eagle (−4) subtracts 2 from its Fighting totals when attacking a Tiny fairy (−6).

Scale Modifiers
Modifier Scale & Examples
−6 Tiny: Armor joint, baseball, mouse
−4 Very Small: Human hand or head, basketball, house cat
−2 Small: Human limb, bobcat
— Normal: Human, bull, horse
+2 Large: Hippo, most vehicles
+4 Huge: Dragon, whale
+6 Gargantuan: Building, kaiju, ship

Called Shots & Target Size

Use the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Scale} of the target when making Called Shots against creatures, not their Scale. If an archer wants to shoot the eye of a mature dragon, for example, use the Scale of the eye, not the dragon.

Hitting certain vital areas have extra effects listed under @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Called Shots}.

Stunned

Creature abilities, the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Stun]{stun} power, electrical hazards, or other shocks to the brain or nervous system make a character essentially helpless until they manage to shake it off.

Restart the process if a stunned character is stunned again.

Stunned characters

  • Are @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Distracted} (this is removed at the end of a victim’s next turn as usual)
  • Are @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Vulnerable} Vulnerable (this remains until a victim recover from being Stunned)
  • Fall prone (or to their knees, GM’s call)
  • Can’t move or take any actions
  • Don’t count toward the "@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Gang Up} bonus

Recovery: At the start of a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned} char­acter’s turn, he makes a Vigor roll as a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{free action}. Success means he’s no longer Stunned but remains Vulnerable until the end of his next turn. With a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise}, his Vulnerable state goes away at the end of this turn.

Support

Sometimes characters may want to cooperate or help an ally with a task. If so, and the GM decides it’s possible, supporting characters roll the relevant skill (as an action if the game is in rounds) and declare which of their ally’s skills they’re attempting to Support.

Success grants the ally +1 to one skill total this round, and a raise adds +2. A @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Critical Failure} on the support roll subtracts 2 from the lead’s total— sometimes extra hands just get in the way!

Remove all Support bonuses at the end of the recipient’s turn, whether he used them or not (perhaps by taking an action different than the one he was Supported for).

The maximum bonus from all Support rolls is +4. Strength checks are an exception and have no maximum bonus since more muscle can always manage more mass.

Players and GMs should be creative when making Support rolls. An adventurer with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Survival]{Survival}, for example, might make a roll to find useful herbs for an ally attempting a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Healing]{Healing} check, or a character with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Academics]{Academics} might recall historical information helpful to a wizard doing research on an ancient relic.

General encouragement (a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion} roll) such as “You can do it!” or “Check your six!” are perfectly acceptable, but at the GM’s discretion lose effectiveness if repeated.

Example: The heroes mount up for a day’s ride. Spooked by a pack of wolves, the horses bolt. The cleric, having no @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Riding]{Riding} skill, finds herself in danger of losing control of the mount. The paladin shouts “Hold the reins loosely!” She rolls Riding and gets a raise. The cleric adds +2 to the unskilled Riding roll to control her horse.

Surprise

Combat often starts before everyone involved is prepared. An ambush, a sudden double-cross, or a trap might all give one side in a fight an advantage. When this happens, the ambushers are automatically on @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Hold}. Deal them in as usual anyway in case one of them gets a Joker.

The victims of the attack make a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice} roll. Those who make it are dealt in as usual. Those who fail get no Action Card and can’t act in the first round of combat.

See the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Stealth]{Stealth} skill if someone attempts a sneak attack before the round begins.

Test

Support VS. Test

The Support option can be used against an opponent narratively, but the only effect it can have is as detailed above. If a character wants to “trip up” an ogre to help a friend make a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} roll against it, for example, she can add +1 or +2 to his roll, but she doesn’t actually trip the ogre. It’s not made @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{prone}, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Distracted or Vulnerable} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} as it might if she had used the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Test} option.

The advantage for a player in making a Support roll over a Test is to help an ally and avoid a more difficult opposed roll for the Test (even though narratively it might seem like it should be an opposed roll).

The @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Support} option allows a character to help out her allies. Test is the opposite— it lets him make things more difficult for his foes! Tests include embarrassing an opponent, throwing sand in his eyes, staring him down with a steely gaze, or anything else a clever player can think of to rattle his enemy and put him off-balance.

To perform a Test, the player describes the action and works with the GM to determine the most appropriate skill to roll for it. Tests are resisted instinctively, so the “attacker’s” skill roll is opposed by the attribute it’s linked to. Tripping someone is an @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll versus Agility since that’s what Athletics is linked to. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunt} is linked to Smarts, so verbally humiliating someone is resisted by that attribute. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting}, when used as a Test instead of an actual attack, isn’t compared to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Parry}— it’s opposed by Agility. Whatever skill is used, performing a Test is an action.

If the attacker wins the opposed roll, he can choose to make his foe @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Distracted or ­Vulnerable}. If he wins with a raise, the target is also @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}, and there may be other subjective effects as the GM allows, such as a tripped foe being knocked @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{prone}.

Modifiers: The GM must determine which modifiers apply to a Test. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting}, for example, should include @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Range}, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Cover}, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination}, etc. A hero with a bonus to his Parry does not add it to his Agility when challenged with a Fighting roll, however, because the defender resists with Agility— not his Parry.

Take the details into consideration as well— using a shameful secret to hit a rival’s ego where it hurts, for example, might be worth a +2 bonus to the attacker.

Repetition: Using the same or similar action repeatedly quickly grows less effective, so the GM shouldn't allow players to use the same tactics, insults, or threats more than once an encounter.

Additional Dice: If characters have addi­tional dice for a Test, such as when using a weapon with a high Rate of Fire, he may roll all the dice but takes only the highest as his Test total. He doesn’t get multiple results and he can’t spread them out to other targets.

Dungeoneering

When heroes delve into dungeons— or ruins or even buildings— combat can get cramped.

In Pathfinder for Savage Worlds, creative use of these Situational Rules give the characters options during combat. Instead of just waiting for your turn to get through a door and attack, for example, your hero can attempt other actions to make an impact with teamwork.

  • Support: Coordinate your actions and use Support to ensure success. For example, the paladin tries to Push past an ogre blocking the entrance to the villain’s chamber, hoping to create space for the fighter. The rogue rolls Support using @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunt} (“Is that all you got?”) to assist with the paladin’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Push} attempt.
  • Test: Coordinate tactics to make it harder for enemies to fight back. In the Push example above, the sorcerer— who wants to save @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Power Points]{Power Points} for attacks on the villain— can @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Test} the ogre with Taunt. Knowing it speaks Giant, she shouts insults in that tongue. If she succeeds on the opposed roll, she makes the ogre @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Distracted}, which helps the paladin win the opposed Push.

Touch Attack

A character who simply wants to touch a foe (usually to deliver a magical effect of some kind) may add +2 to his @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} roll.

Two Weapons

A character armed with two melee weapons adds +1 to his @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} rolls if his foe has a single weapon or is unarmed, and has no shield. It adds no bonus against creatures with @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Natural Weapons}.

Wielding two small ranged weapons offers no special advantage other than additional ammunition or narrative embellishments.

Those wanting to specialize further can take the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Two-Weapon Fighting]{Two-Weapon Fighting} Edge.

Unarmed Defender

It’s difficult to parry a blade with one’s bare hands. An attacker armed with a melee weapon adds +2 to his @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} attacks if his foe has no weapon or shield. (This doesn’t stack with @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{The Drop}.)

Unstable Platform

A character attempting to fire or throw a ranged weapon from the back of a horse or other mount, a moving vehicle, or other “unstable platform” subtracts 2 from his @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (throwing) or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} totals.

Vehicles

Attacking from or on vehicles such as ships, carriages, or airships works as usual— see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02vehicles000000]{Vehicles}.

Wild Attack

Sometimes a desperate character may want to throw caution to the wind and attack with everything he’s got.

A Wild Attack adds +2 to the character’s @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (throwing) attacks and resulting damage rolls for the turn, but he is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Vulnerable} until the end of his next turn (not this one).

Wild Attacks can be used with multiple attacks, such as from @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Multi-Actions} or the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Frenzy]{Frenzy} and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Sweep]{Sweep} Edges. It can't be combined with a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Desperate Attack}.

Withdrawing From Melee

Whenever a character retreats from melee, all adjacent non-@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} and non-@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned} opponents get an immediate Free Attack (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Free Attacks}).

Example: Our druid is surrounded by three bandits. She must get to a wounded sorcerer. She takes the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Defend} option (increasing her @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Parry} by +4) and backs away from the bandits. All three of her opponents get a Free Attack, at +2 for Ganging Up. Fortunately, the druid’s Parry bonus fends them off and she makes her way to her injured friend.

The Adventure Tool Kit.name: The Adventure Tool Kit
The Adventure Tool Kit.text:
The Adventure
Tool kit

The following chapter contains tools the Game Master can use for all the special situations that often come up in a game, such as:

  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04allies00000000]{Allies}: Managing Extras under the player character’s control.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04downtime000000]{Downtime}: A way to determine the benefits of character activity between adventures.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04dramatictask00]{Dramatic Tasks}: Add tension and drama to situations like crossing a vast chasm.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04fear0000000000]{Fear}: The effects of overwhelming terror.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{Hazards}: The effects of scorching heat, bitter cold, poison, and more.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04interludes0000]{Interludes}: Narrative storytelling for long trips or to reveal bits about the player characters’ backstories.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04massbattles000]{Mass Battles}: Desperate last stands against incredible odds between armies.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04networking0000]{Networking}: Gathering information (the nice way or the not-so-nice way).
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04theplanes00000]{The Planes}: Information about other Planes of existence.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04quickencount00]{Quick Encounters}: A fast and easy way to resolve fights, heists, or capers when pressed for time.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04socialconfli00]{Social Conflict}: Run a court trial, plead for aid, or convince a crowd.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04travel00000000]{Travel}: Figure out how long it takes for the party to cross tracts of Golarion.

Allies.name: Allies
Allies.text:
Allies

Allies play a big part in Savage Pathfinder games. They serve as troops under your hero’s command in war, loyal retainers serving strongholds, or fellow fighters in glorious rebellions against oppression.

When to Use These Rules: Use these rules to help keep track of the party’s followers and give them a little extra personality to play off of as well.

The Basics: Players create, control, and track their own followers and nonplayer character allies.

Using Allies

Keeping up with allies in Savage Pathfinder is simple. Just download the Ally Sheet from our website and fill in the blanks.

Allied @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Extras} are divided up among all the players to control. This is a very important part of Savage Pathfinder because our adventures often feature allied bands of skilled hirelings, fellow grunts, or loyal retainers, and the game is designed to handle them quickly and easily. It’s also designed for the players to control them — not the Game Master.

It doesn’t matter whether the characters control the allies, only that the players do. This keeps everyone involved in the action even if his hero is out of the fight, and makes running large combats much easier and more fun for everyone. Of course the GM can always take charge of Extras when the need arises, but with good roleplayers this is rarely necessary.

Allied Personalities

You can add a little flavor to your allies by rolling on the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-tables.Allied Personalities]{Allied Personalities} table. Jot down the keyword on the Ally Sheet so you and your Game Master have a little insight into each particular ally’s character.

Consider these general impressions with no particular game effect. They help both the player and GM decide just how an ally might react in a given situation.

If a party of adventurers tasks a retainer with keeping watch, it's helpful to know which ones are Observant and which ones are Lazy!

Allied Personalties
d20 Personality d20 Personality
1 Treacherous 11 Crude
2 Cruel 12 Agile
3 Old 13 Observant
4 Happy 14 Clueless
5 Experience 15 Mysterious
6 Gung-Ho 16 Creative
7 Lazy 17 Artistic
8 Sneaky 18 Fearless
9 Bright 19 Cowardly
10 Young 20 Heroic

Allies & Advancement

Allies can improve their abilities as well. See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01advancement000]{Advancement}.

Ammo

Keeping track of ammunition for all your allies can be difficult. Here’s an easy and dramatic way to handle this problem.

The ammo level of each group of allied @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Extras} starts at Very High, High (the usual level), Low, or Out, as determined by the GM.

After each fight, the ammo automatically drops a level. This makes for dramatic situations and realistic logistical problems while eliminating the bookkeeping.

The GM can always decide otherwise, of course. Perhaps the troops are told to fight with hand weapons instead of their bows and crossbows, or they don’t get to fire off more than a couple of shots before the fight is over.

Typical Allies

Here are a few typical archetypes you might use for your Savage Pathfinder game. Fill in any additional @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{skills} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edgesummarie00]{Edges} as you see fit. A group of rangers, for example, should have the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Survival]{Survival} skill, while cavalrymen should have @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Riding]{Riding}. Add appropriate @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{gear} for the situation as well.

Soldier

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Soldier]{See the actor here.}

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4, Spirit d6, Strength d6, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d6, Common Knowledge d6, Fighting d6, Intimidation d6, Notice d6, Persuasion d6, Shooting d6, Stealth d4

Pace: 6; Parry: 5; Toughness: 5

Hindrances: —

Edges: Soldier

Experienced Soldier

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Experienced Soldier]{See the actor here.}

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d6, Spirit d6, Strength d8, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d6, Common Knowledge d6, Fighting d8, Intimidation d6, Notice d6, Persuasion d6, Shooting d8, Stealth d6

Creative Combat.name: Creative Combat
Creative Combat.text:
Creative Combat

Creative Combat is an optional rule a Game Master may allow to give @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Tests} more varied results. It’s especially useful if a group prefers a slightly more pulpy or swashbuckling feel.

When to Use These Rules: Use these rules when you want Tests to have a little more variety.

The Basics: Roll on the table when a character Tests a foe with a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise}.

Tests of Mettle

Creative Combat occurs only when the game is in rounds. A regular success on a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Test} works as usual. If a character succeeds with a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise}, she can decide if she wants to take the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} result or roll on the Creative Combat table. She can decide if she wants to make her foe @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Distracted or Vulnerable} after she rolls on the table.

Example: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Merisiel]{Merisiel} battles an ogre on the edge of a cliff. She feints the clumsy brute and gets a raise. The GM rolls on the Creative Combat table and gets a Setback. She decides the ogre has to make an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Agility} roll or fall off the cliff. Merisiel makes the creature Distracted so it has a greater chance of failure!


Creative Combat
2d6 Result
2 Second Wind: The foe hesitates, giving your hero time to catch her breath. She may remove a level of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Fatigue} or a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound} (her choice).
